template.name: AWS_Generative AI Application Builder_MCP Server
template.desc:
Generative AI Application Builder on AWS

Building and managing agentic AI applications can be challenging for teams without deep AI infrastructure or orchestration expertise. Generative AI Application Builder (GAAB) on AWS eliminates that complexity by unifying all the key components of modern agentic systems into one integrated solution. GAAB brings together the Model Context Protocol (MCP), agents, and multi-agent orchestration with built-in authentication, permissioning, networking, and application managementâ€”so teams can focus on iterating and improving their applications instead of managing infrastructure.

With GAAB, you can deploy local MCP servers as remote endpoints using AWS Lambda, container images, or OpenAPI and Smithy API specifications. The platform enables developers to create agents, assign MCP tools, and orchestrate complex behaviors through the Agent-as-a-Tool framework. Once an agentic application is ready, teams can collaborate instantly by accessing the application out of the box or integrating it with their own client through a single WebSocket connection.

GAAB accelerates the path from prototype to production by simplifying the deployment, management, and scaling of secure, extensible agentic applications built on AWS.

 

Deploy Remote MCP Servers

The MCP Server use case enables you to quickly deploy and manage remote MCP Servers from the Management Dashboard. Use an image, a Lambda, an OpenAPI spec, or a Smitty file to quickly deploy and host a remote MCP Server for your Agent Builder and orchestration use cases.

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Deny creation and usage of Bedrock API keys
countermeasure.desc:
• Deny the action iam:CreateServiceSpecificCredential to prevent the creation of long-term Bedrock API keys. Where business exceptions are required, restrict creation with IAM condition keys, such as setting iam:ServiceSpecificCredentialServiceName to bedrock.amazonaws.com and limiting iam:ServiceSpecificCredentialAgeDays to the minimum acceptable value (e.g., 90 days).
  • Deny the action bedrock:CallWithBearerToken to block the use of Bedrock bearer API keys, regardless of type. Where partial enforcement is necessary, scope the condition bedrock:bearerTokenType to explicitly block either SHORT_TERM or LONG_TERM keys.

References

  • Control permissions for generating and using Amazon Bedrock API keys

PR.PT-3: The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1018 - User Account Management||ATLAS - AML.M0019 - Control Access to AI Models and Data in Production

countermeasure.name: Deploy models in isolated accounts to restrict unauthorized access
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all AWS Bedrock models are deployed in isolated AWS accounts, limiting access to authorized users and preventing unauthorized parties, including model providers, from accessing or manipulating the models. Use account isolation strategies such as AWS Organizations and service control policies (SCPs) to restrict access and control resource sharing between accounts. This setup enhances security by ensuring that models are protected from external threats and unauthorized internal actions, while allowing for stricter governance and monitoring of account-specific activities. Regularly audit account configurations and permissions to maintain strong isolation boundaries.

countermeasure.name: Detect and alert on Bedrock bearer key usage
countermeasure.desc:
• Configure detections for Bedrock bearer key usage by alerting on CloudTrail events with additionalEventData.callWithBearerToken=true. Distinguish normal service activity from suspicious access by correlating principal, source IP, and user agent, and prioritize findings originating from unexpected principals or networks.
  • Monitor iam:CreateServiceSpecificCredential events where requestParameters.service equals bedrock.amazonaws.com to detect attempted or successful creation of long-term Bedrock API keys.
  • Enable detections for sensitive Bedrock changes (e.g., creation, update, or deletion of guardrails) and treat these as high-priority when they follow bearer-token activity.

References

  • Monitor Amazon Bedrock API calls using CloudTrail

countermeasure.name: Implement API request signing with access keys or temporary credentials
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure Amazon Bedrock access uses IAM roles with SigV4-signed SDK/CLI requests; do not use Bedrock bearer API keys unless explicitly approved with compensating controls. If Bedrock API keys exist, enforce minimal permissions and short lifetimes, and apply the dedicated controls to deny creation and usage of bearer keys.

Use temporary credentials via AWS STS and enforce strict IAM policies. Configure clients to sign requests (SigV4) and validate that unsigned/bearer requests are rejected. Rotate credentials regularly and monitor for anomalies.

Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/bedrock/latest/userguide/api-keys-permissions.html

countermeasure.name: Isolate foundation model tuning data in private instances to prevent leakage
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that when tuning a foundation model in AWS Bedrock, all customer data is isolated in a private instance to prevent unauthorized access or reuse by model providers. Use account-specific resources such as AWS PrivateLink and VPC to securely connect to the Bedrock service without exposing data to external networks. Implement strict access controls to limit who can view and interact with the tuning data. Regularly monitor and audit resource usage to confirm data remains isolated and protected from unintended exposure or reuse, ensuring compliance with privacy regulations and safeguarding sensitive information.

reference.name: Security in Amazon Bedrock

countermeasure.name: Prefer roles and SigV4 over Bedrock API keys
countermeasure.desc:
• Use IAM roles and SigV4-signed SDK or CLI calls for accessing Amazon Bedrock instead of bearer API keys. This ensures requests are cryptographically signed and traceable, reducing the risk of credential misuse.
  • If the use of API keys cannot be fully avoided, enforce strict least-privilege policies, apply the shortest possible key lifetimes, and configure dedicated monitoring to detect and respond to bearer token usage.

References

  • A new type of long-lived key on AWS: Bedrock API keys

countermeasure.name: Reduce privileges of auto-created IAM user
countermeasure.desc:
• For any existing long-term Bedrock API keys, remove the AWS-managed AmazonBedrockLimitedAccess policy, as it grants broad permissions that exceed most workload requirements.
  • Replace it with custom IAM policies that follow the principle of least privilege, granting only the actions strictly required by the workload (for example, bedrock:InvokeModel).
  • Regularly audit attached policies to ensure no over-privileged permissions remain and that policies continue to align with current operational needs.

References

  • AmazonBedrockLimitedAccess policy reference

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1025 - Privileged Process Integrity||ATLAS - AML.M0005 - Control Access to AI Models and Data at Rest

countermeasure.name: Scan for Bedrock API keys in code and artifacts
countermeasure.desc:
• Add Bedrock-specific patterns to secret scanning to detect both long- and short-term keys. Include a rule for long-term keys prefixed with ABSK and a rule for short-term keys that include bedrock-api-key-.
  • Integrate these patterns with GitHub secret scanning (including push protection where available) and CI pre-commit hooks so commits are blocked or flagged before merging.
  • On detection, automatically revoke the exposed key, rotate any dependent credentials, and open an incident ticket with links to the offending commit or artifact for traceability.

References

  • Gitleaks rule for Bedrock long-term keys

countermeasure.name: Use SourceArn and SourceAccount conditions to limit access to trusted entities
countermeasure.desc: Implement the aws:SourceArn and aws:SourceAccount conditions in resource-based policies to ensure that AWS Bedrock resources are only accessed by trusted sources. These conditions restrict access based on the specific ARN or AWS account making the request, reducing the risk of unauthorized access. To apply this control, update your IAM policies with conditions that validate the source of the request and ensure that only allowed entities, such as specific roles or trusted accounts, can interact with your Bedrock resources. This helps prevent unauthorized cross-account or cross-service actions that could compromise your environment.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management||ATLAS - AML.M0005 - Control Access to AI Models and Data at Rest

countermeasure.name: Validate and sanitize input to prevent malicious patterns in Bedrock API requests
countermeasure.desc: Ensure all user input sent to the AWS Bedrock API is thoroughly validated and sanitized to prevent special characters or malicious patterns from being processed. Input validation should be performed on both server-side and client-side to filter out dangerous inputs like SQL-like commands or unexpected formats. Implement input sanitization to escape or remove special characters, reducing the risk of injection attacks. Regularly test applications with security tools such as static analysis, dynamic testing, and penetration testing to identify and mitigate potential vulnerabilities related to input handling. This will protect your Bedrock environment from prompt injection attacks and other input-based exploits.

reference.name: Prompt injection security

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Confuse deputy attack
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
A confused deputy attack occurs when AWS Bedrock is tricked into performing actions on behalf of an unauthorized user or service. This happens when cross-service permissions are misconfigured, allowing an attacker to leverage Bedrockâ€™s privileges to access or manipulate resources they would not normally have access to.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers or compromised services that exploit weak cross-service permissions.
  • Misconfigured resource policies that fail to validate the origin of requests.

Impacts
Unauthorized data access, resource manipulation, and potential service disruptions, leading to security breaches and data leaks.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker uses a misconfigured cross-service role to trick Bedrock into accessing sensitive resources like model configurations or datasets, which they are not authorized to access.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism||ATLAS - AML.T0012 - Valid Accounts

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data privacy violation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data privacy violations occur when sensitive or personal data processed by AWS Bedrock is improperly accessed, exposed, or misused, breaching compliance standards such as GDPR or HIPAA.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Insiders or external attackers exploiting misconfigurations in Bedrock.
  • Third-party model providers mishandling data.

Impacts
Financial penalties, reputational damage, and legal consequences due to non-compliance with privacy regulations.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits weak access controls to download sensitive customer data used in fine-tuning models.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1078 - Valid Accounts||ATLAS - AML.T0048.001 - Reputational Harm

threat.name: Insecure API access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Insecure API access occurs when unauthorized parties exploit weak access controls or improper API configurations, allowing them to misuse AWS Bedrock's API, leading to unauthorized actions, data leaks, or exposure of sensitive resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers exploiting weak API authentication or improperly configured API keys.
  • Insiders abusing improperly scoped API permissions.

Impacts
Data theft, unauthorized model access, or abuse of resources, leading to financial loss and regulatory non-compliance.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker leverages exposed API keys to access Bedrock resources, extracting sensitive data used for model customization.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1102 - Web Service||ATLAS - AML.T0040 - AI Model Inference API Access

threat.name: Model theft or misuse
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Model theft or misuse happens when unauthorized individuals gain access to AWS Bedrock's foundational or fine-tuned models. This can lead to intellectual property theft, unauthorized usage, or exploitation of proprietary models for malicious or unintended purposes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers exploiting misconfigurations or weak access controls to retrieve models.
  • Insiders with excessive privileges accessing and leaking sensitive models.

Impacts
Loss of proprietary model data, financial loss, damage to intellectual property, and competitive disadvantage.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains unauthorized access to a custom fine-tuned model through improperly secured APIs and uses it to replicate the model for personal gain or to sell it to competitors.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism||ATLAS - AML.T0044 - Full AI Model Access

threat.name: Prompt injection attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Prompt injection attacks occur when an attacker manipulates input prompts to deceive or control the behavior of AI models in AWS Bedrock. These attacks exploit the model's ability to process natural language input, injecting malicious commands or misleading data, resulting in unintended outputs or actions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers inputting malicious prompts to alter the modelâ€™s response.
  • Insiders crafting prompts to manipulate model behavior or extract sensitive information.

Impacts
Manipulated model outputs, potential exposure of confidential data, reputational damage, and compromised decision-making in AI-driven applications.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker submits a carefully crafted prompt that causes the model to reveal sensitive data or produce misleading results, leading to incorrect or damaging business decisions.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter||ATLAS - AML.T0051 - LLM Prompt Injection

threat.name: Abuse of Bedrock bearer API keys
threat.desc:
Abuse of Bedrock bearer API keys occurs when long-term or short-term keys are used instead of standard AWS authentication. Long-term keys automatically create IAM users with broad default permissions, while short-term keys are generated client-side without CloudTrail creation visibility. As bearer tokens, leaked keys can be misused to access or modify Bedrock resources outside of intended security controls.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Insiders generating or retaining long-term Bedrock API keys.
  • External attackers obtaining leaked bearer tokens from public repositories or compromised systems.
  • Malicious actors abusing the over-privileged AmazonBedrockLimitedAccess policy assigned to auto-created IAM users.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to Bedrock models, datasets, or guardrails.
  • Potential deletion or modification of security guardrails.
  • Data confidentiality and integrity risks from model misuse.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A leaked long-term Bedrock API key on GitHub is used to invoke Bedrock models and disable guardrails.
  • An attacker compromises a developer machine and retrieves a short-term bearer token, allowing them to run inference requests undetected.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1134 - Access Token Manipulation||ATLAS - AML.T0055 - Unsecured Credentials

countermeasure.name: Use SourceArn and SourceAccount conditions to limit access to trusted entities
countermeasure.desc: Implement the aws:SourceArn and aws:SourceAccount conditions in resource-based policies to ensure that AWS Bedrock resources are only accessed by trusted sources. These conditions restrict access based on the specific ARN or AWS account making the request, reducing the risk of unauthorized access. To apply this control, update your IAM policies with conditions that validate the source of the request and ensure that only allowed entities, such as specific roles or trusted accounts, can interact with your Bedrock resources. This helps prevent unauthorized cross-account or cross-service actions that could compromise your environment.

countermeasure.name: Validate and sanitize input to prevent malicious patterns in Bedrock API requests
countermeasure.desc: Ensure all user input sent to the AWS Bedrock API is thoroughly validated and sanitized to prevent special characters or malicious patterns from being processed. Input validation should be performed on both server-side and client-side to filter out dangerous inputs like SQL-like commands or unexpected formats. Implement input sanitization to escape or remove special characters, reducing the risk of injection attacks. Regularly test applications with security tools such as static analysis, dynamic testing, and penetration testing to identify and mitigate potential vulnerabilities related to input handling. This will protect your Bedrock environment from prompt injection attacks and other input-based exploits.

reference.name: Prompt injection security

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Confuse deputy attack
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
A confused deputy attack occurs when AWS Bedrock is tricked into performing actions on behalf of an unauthorized user or service. This happens when cross-service permissions are misconfigured, allowing an attacker to leverage Bedrockâ€™s privileges to access or manipulate resources they would not normally have access to.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers or compromised services that exploit weak cross-service permissions.
  • Misconfigured resource policies that fail to validate the origin of requests.

Impacts
Unauthorized data access, resource manipulation, and potential service disruptions, leading to security breaches and data leaks.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker uses a misconfigured cross-service role to trick Bedrock into accessing sensitive resources like model configurations or datasets, which they are not authorized to access.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism||ATLAS - AML.T0012 - Valid Accounts

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Prompt injection attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Prompt injection attacks occur when an attacker manipulates input prompts to deceive or control the behavior of AI models in AWS Bedrock. These attacks exploit the model's ability to process natural language input, injecting malicious commands or misleading data, resulting in unintended outputs or actions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers inputting malicious prompts to alter the modelâ€™s response.
  • Insiders crafting prompts to manipulate model behavior or extract sensitive information.

Impacts
Manipulated model outputs, potential exposure of confidential data, reputational damage, and compromised decision-making in AI-driven applications.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker submits a carefully crafted prompt that causes the model to reveal sensitive data or produce misleading results, leading to incorrect or damaging business decisions.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter||ATLAS - AML.T0051 - LLM Prompt Injection

threat.name: Data privacy violation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data privacy violations occur when sensitive or personal data processed by AWS Bedrock is improperly accessed, exposed, or misused, breaching compliance standards such as GDPR or HIPAA.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Insiders or external attackers exploiting misconfigurations in Bedrock.
  • Third-party model providers mishandling data.

Impacts
Financial penalties, reputational damage, and legal consequences due to non-compliance with privacy regulations.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits weak access controls to download sensitive customer data used in fine-tuning models.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1078 - Valid Accounts||ATLAS - AML.T0048.001 - Reputational Harm

threat.name: Insecure API access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Insecure API access occurs when unauthorized parties exploit weak access controls or improper API configurations, allowing them to misuse AWS Bedrock's API, leading to unauthorized actions, data leaks, or exposure of sensitive resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers exploiting weak API authentication or improperly configured API keys.
  • Insiders abusing improperly scoped API permissions.

Impacts
Data theft, unauthorized model access, or abuse of resources, leading to financial loss and regulatory non-compliance.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker leverages exposed API keys to access Bedrock resources, extracting sensitive data used for model customization.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1102 - Web Service||ATLAS - AML.T0040 - AI Model Inference API Access

threat.name: Model theft or misuse
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Model theft or misuse happens when unauthorized individuals gain access to AWS Bedrock's foundational or fine-tuned models. This can lead to intellectual property theft, unauthorized usage, or exploitation of proprietary models for malicious or unintended purposes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers exploiting misconfigurations or weak access controls to retrieve models.
  • Insiders with excessive privileges accessing and leaking sensitive models.

Impacts
Loss of proprietary model data, financial loss, damage to intellectual property, and competitive disadvantage.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains unauthorized access to a custom fine-tuned model through improperly secured APIs and uses it to replicate the model for personal gain or to sell it to competitors.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism||ATLAS - AML.T0044 - Full AI Model Access

threat.name: Abuse of Bedrock bearer API keys
threat.desc:
Abuse of Bedrock bearer API keys occurs when long-term or short-term keys are used instead of standard AWS authentication. Long-term keys automatically create IAM users with broad default permissions, while short-term keys are generated client-side without CloudTrail creation visibility. As bearer tokens, leaked keys can be misused to access or modify Bedrock resources outside of intended security controls.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Insiders generating or retaining long-term Bedrock API keys.
  • External attackers obtaining leaked bearer tokens from public repositories or compromised systems.
  • Malicious actors abusing the over-privileged AmazonBedrockLimitedAccess policy assigned to auto-created IAM users.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to Bedrock models, datasets, or guardrails.
  • Potential deletion or modification of security guardrails.
  • Data confidentiality and integrity risks from model misuse.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A leaked long-term Bedrock API key on GitHub is used to invoke Bedrock models and disable guardrails.
  • An attacker compromises a developer machine and retrieves a short-term bearer token, allowing them to run inference requests undetected.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1134 - Access Token Manipulation||ATLAS - AML.T0055 - Unsecured Credentials

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Deny creation and usage of Bedrock API keys
countermeasure.desc:
• Deny the action iam:CreateServiceSpecificCredential to prevent the creation of long-term Bedrock API keys. Where business exceptions are required, restrict creation with IAM condition keys, such as setting iam:ServiceSpecificCredentialServiceName to bedrock.amazonaws.com and limiting iam:ServiceSpecificCredentialAgeDays to the minimum acceptable value (e.g., 90 days).
  • Deny the action bedrock:CallWithBearerToken to block the use of Bedrock bearer API keys, regardless of type. Where partial enforcement is necessary, scope the condition bedrock:bearerTokenType to explicitly block either SHORT_TERM or LONG_TERM keys.

References

  • Control permissions for generating and using Amazon Bedrock API keys

countermeasure.name: Deploy models in isolated accounts to restrict unauthorized access
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all AWS Bedrock models are deployed in isolated AWS accounts, limiting access to authorized users and preventing unauthorized parties, including model providers, from accessing or manipulating the models. Use account isolation strategies such as AWS Organizations and service control policies (SCPs) to restrict access and control resource sharing between accounts. This setup enhances security by ensuring that models are protected from external threats and unauthorized internal actions, while allowing for stricter governance and monitoring of account-specific activities. Regularly audit account configurations and permissions to maintain strong isolation boundaries.

reference.name: Generative AI for the AWS SRA

countermeasure.name: Detect and alert on Bedrock bearer key usage
countermeasure.desc:
• Configure detections for Bedrock bearer key usage by alerting on CloudTrail events with additionalEventData.callWithBearerToken=true. Distinguish normal service activity from suspicious access by correlating principal, source IP, and user agent, and prioritize findings originating from unexpected principals or networks.
  • Monitor iam:CreateServiceSpecificCredential events where requestParameters.service equals bedrock.amazonaws.com to detect attempted or successful creation of long-term Bedrock API keys.
  • Enable detections for sensitive Bedrock changes (e.g., creation, update, or deletion of guardrails) and treat these as high-priority when they follow bearer-token activity.

References

  • Monitor Amazon Bedrock API calls using CloudTrail

countermeasure.name: Implement API request signing with access keys or temporary credentials
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure Amazon Bedrock access uses IAM roles with SigV4-signed SDK/CLI requests; do not use Bedrock bearer API keys unless explicitly approved with compensating controls. If Bedrock API keys exist, enforce minimal permissions and short lifetimes, and apply the dedicated controls to deny creation and usage of bearer keys.

Use temporary credentials via AWS STS and enforce strict IAM policies. Configure clients to sign requests (SigV4) and validate that unsigned/bearer requests are rejected. Rotate credentials regularly and monitor for anomalies.

Reference: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/bedrock/latest/userguide/api-keys-permissions.html

Implement strict access controls to limit who can view and interact with the tuning data. Regularly monitor and audit resource usage to confirm data remains isolated and protected from unintended exposure or reuse, ensuring compliance with privacy regulations and safeguarding sensitive information.

Model theft or misuse happens when unauthorized individuals gain access to AWS Bedrock's foundational or fine-tuned models. This can lead to intellectual property theft, unauthorized usage, or exploitation of proprietary models for malicious or unintended purposes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers exploiting misconfigurations or weak access controls to retrieve models.
  • Insiders with excessive privileges accessing and leaking sensitive models.

Impacts
Loss of proprietary model data, financial loss, damage to intellectual property, and competitive disadvantage.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains unauthorized access to a custom fine-tuned model through improperly secured APIs and uses it to replicate the model for personal gain or to sell it to competitors.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism||ATLAS - AML.T0044 - Full AI Model Access

threat.name: Prompt injection attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Prompt injection attacks occur when an attacker manipulates input prompts to deceive or control the behavior of AI models in AWS Bedrock. These attacks exploit the model's ability to process natural language input, injecting malicious commands or misleading data, resulting in unintended outputs or actions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers inputting malicious prompts to alter the modelâ€™s response.
  • Insiders crafting prompts to manipulate model behavior or extract sensitive information.

Impacts
Manipulated model outputs, potential exposure of confidential data, reputational damage, and compromised decision-making in AI-driven applications.

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker submits a carefully crafted prompt that causes the model to reveal sensitive data or produce misleading results, leading to incorrect or damaging business decisions.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter||ATLAS - AML.T0051 - LLM Prompt Injection

threat.name: Abuse of Bedrock bearer API keys
threat.desc:
Abuse of Bedrock bearer API keys occurs when long-term or short-term keys are used instead of standard AWS authentication. Long-term keys automatically create IAM users with broad default permissions, while short-term keys are generated client-side without CloudTrail creation visibility. As bearer tokens, leaked keys can be misused to access or modify Bedrock resources outside of intended security controls.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Insiders generating or retaining long-term Bedrock API keys.
  • External attackers obtaining leaked bearer tokens from public repositories or compromised systems.
  • Malicious actors abusing the over-privileged AmazonBedrockLimitedAccess policy assigned to auto-created IAM users.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to Bedrock models, datasets, or guardrails.
  • Potential deletion or modification of security guardrails.
  • Data confidentiality and integrity risks from model misuse.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A leaked long-term Bedrock API key on GitHub is used to invoke Bedrock models and disable guardrails.
  • An attacker compromises a developer machine and retrieves a short-term bearer token, allowing them to run inference requests undetected.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1134 - Access Token Manipulation||ATLAS - AML.T0055 - Unsecured Credentials

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-308
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-308: Use of Single-factor Authentication The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme. While the use of multiple authentication schemes is simply piling on more complexity on top of authentication, it is inestimably valuable to have such measures of redundancy. The use of weak, reused, and common passwords is rampant on the internet. Without the added protection of multiple authentication schemes, a single mistake can result in the compromise of an account. For this reason, if multiple schemes are possible and also easy to use, they should be implemented and required.

weakness.name: CWE-346
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-346: Origin Validation Error The product does not properly verify that the source of data or communication is valid.

weakness.name: CWE-613
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-613: Insufficient Session Expiration According to WASC, "Insufficient Session Expiration is when a web site permits an attacker to reuse old session credentials or session IDs for authorization."

countermeasure.name: Apply fine-grained identity policies
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance security and ensure precise control over user access to resources, implement fine-grained identity policies using AWS Cognito. This approach involves creating specific IAM policies that tightly control what authenticated and unauthenticated users can access.

Begin by defining user roles and associating them with appropriate IAM policies. For instance, authenticated users might have policies granting them access to user-specific resources, whereas unauthenticated users might have restricted access.

Here's a step-by-step guide for a cloud engineer:

  1. Create an IAM Role for Authenticated Users
    • Navigate to the IAM console and create a new role for authenticated users.
    • Attach a policy to this role that grants permissions to access only specific resources. Use JSON policy documents for greater precision. Refer to the Cognito IAM roles documentation for example policies.
  2. Create an IAM Role for Unauthenticated Users
    • Similarly, create another role for unauthenticated users, ensuring the policy attached to this role is more restrictive.
  3. Associate Roles with Cognito Identity Pool
    • Navigate to the Cognito console and choose your identity pool.
    • Edit the identity pool settings to assign the roles created above to authenticated and unauthenticated users respectively.
  4. Test the Policies
    • Validate that authenticated users have the correct level of access and that unauthenticated users are appropriately restricted.

For more detailed information, refer to the AWS Cognito security guidelines and specific references on IAM roles.

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1018 - User Account Management

countermeasure.name: Enable multi-factor authentication (MFA)
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of user accounts in AWS Cognito, it is highly recommended to enable Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA). By integrating MFA, an additional layer of protection is provided, reducing the risk of unauthorized access. Follow the guidelines below to implement MFA for your Cognito user pool:

  1. Log in to the AWS Management Console and navigate to the Amazon Cognito service.
  2. Select the user pool for which you want to enable MFA.
  3. In the left-hand navigation pane, choose MFA and verifications.
  4. Under the Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) section, configure your desired MFA settings:
    • Set the MFA status to Optional or Required based on your security needs.
    • Select the MFA methods you wish to enable, such as SMS or TOTP (Time-based One-Time Password).
  5. Configure the SMS or TOTP settings accordingly. For SMS, ensure you have an appropriate SMS role with sufficient permissions. For TOTP, users will need to register their compatible authenticator application.
  6. Save the changes to the user pool settings.

Following these steps will significantly enhance the security posture of your user accounts by leveraging MFA. For further information on configuring MFA with AWS Cognito, refer to the official documentation: Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) in Amazon Cognito.

Additional detailed security considerations can be explored in the AWS Cognito Security Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Restrict access to sensitive user attributes
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing access control for sensitive user attributes in AWS Cognito is essential to enhance security and ensure that such attributes are only accessible by authorized users or services. Follow these guidelines to appropriately restrict access:

Step-by-Step Implementation:

  1. Define Sensitive User Attributes: Identify and label sensitive user attributes in your user pool. These could include PII (Personally Identifiable Information) such as email addresses, phone numbers, or any custom attributes that hold sensitive information.
  2. Configure User Pool Policies: Utilize Amazon Cognitoâ€™s user pool settings to specify which attributes are sensitive and should have restricted access. This can be configured in the user pool attributes settings.
  3. Leverage IAM Policies: Create and enforce IAM policies for the roles and users accessing the user pool. Ensure that these policies adhere to the principle of least privilege, granting the minimum required permissions to access necessary attributes. More details on setting up secure policies can be found in the IAM policy examples.
  4. Use Amazon Cognito Contextual Data: Implement the use of contextual information (such as IP addresses, device types, etc.) to enhance security conditions under which an attribute can be accessed or modified. This approach helps mitigate unauthorized access from unexpected locations or devices.
  5. Audit and Monitor Access: Regularly audit and monitor access to sensitive user attributes using Amazon CloudWatch and AWS CloudTrail. Enable logging and set up alerts for any suspicious or unauthorized access attempts. Refer to the Cognito Streams documentation for guidance on setting up logging and monitoring.
  6. Implement Encryption: Ensure that sensitive user attributes are encrypted both in transit and at rest. AWS Cognito provides built-in encryption for user data at rest, but ensure that transport layer encryption such as TLS is configured correctly for your user pool endpoints. More information can be found in the encryption documentation.

By following these steps and utilizing the features provided by AWS Cognito, cloud engineers can effectively limit access to sensitive user attributes, ensuring that only authorized users or services can access this information. For comprehensive security practices and guidelines, refer to the AWS Cognito Security Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Set up proper session validity periods
countermeasure.desc:
To configure appropriate session validity periods and refresh token policies in AWS Cognito and thereby minimize the window of opportunity for session-based attacks, a cloud engineer should follow these steps:

  • Set Appropriate Session Timeout:

To mitigate potential session-based attacks, it is crucial to configure appropriate session timeout settings. AWS Cognito allows you to set the session duration through the app client settings. Navigate to the AWS Cognito console, select your user pool, and go to the "App clients" settings. Here, configure the Refresh Token Expiration and Token Expiration values to an appropriate timeframe based on your security requirements.

Refer to the following documentation for detailed instructions: AWS Cognito Token Endpoint Documentation.

  • Implement Refresh Token Rotation:

For enhanced security, implement a refresh token rotation policy. This means generating a new refresh token every time the refresh operation is performed. AWS Cognito supports refresh token rotation to further minimize the window in which a stolen token could be used. In the AWS Cognito console, under your user pool settings, enable the PreventUserExistenceErrors option, and configure the refresh token rotation as needed.

For more details, refer to the official security documentation: AWS Cognito Security Best Practices.

  • Regularly Review and Update Policies:

Frequently audit and update your session validity periods and refresh token policies to ensure they align with current security best practices and the evolving threat landscape. This proactive approach helps to continually minimize potential attack vectors.

Consult the following official resource for guidance: AWS Cognito Security Best Practices.

By carefully configuring session validity periods and refresh token policies following AWS Cognito security guidelines, you can significantly reduce the risk of session-based attacks on your applications.

countermeasure.name: Validate JWT tokens
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the proper validation of JWT tokens and confirm their authenticity and integrity, cloud engineers should implement the following countermeasures based on the official AWS Cognito documentation:

1. Verify the Signature: AWS Cognito issues JWT tokens that are signed using a key. To verify the signature, you must use the JSON Web Key Set (JWKS) provided by AWS Cognito. Retrieve the JWKS from the provided URL and use it to validate the token's signature. Reference: AWS Cognito - Verifying a JSON Web Token.

2. Check the Token Expiration: Inspect the "exp" claim in the JWT to ensure that the token has not expired. This check prevents the use of tokens past their validity period, mitigating the risk of replay attacks. Reference for security measures: AWS Cognito Security.

3. Validate the Audience (aud) Claim: The "aud" claim should match the expected audience value configured in your application. This ensures that the token was issued for your specific application and not an unintended audience. Reference: AWS Cognito Security Documentation.

4. Verify the Issuer (iss) Claim: Ensure that the "iss" claim matches the expected issuer URL for your AWS Cognito user pool. This confirms that the token was issued by your trusted user pool. Reference: Verifying a JWT - AWS Cognito.

5. Validate the Token Claims: In addition to the above claims, validate any other token claims that your application relies on for authorization, such as "sub" for user ID and custom claims included in the token. Reference: Security guidelines for AWS Cognito.

6. Regularly Update Your JWKS: AWS rotates the signing keys periodically. Ensure your implementation can handle key rotation by regularly fetching the JWKS and updating your verification mechanisms accordingly. Reference: Using and Verifying Tokens.

By following these guidelines, cloud engineers can robustly validate JWT tokens, ensuring their authenticity and integrity, and thereby significantly enhance the security posture of applications leveraging AWS Cognito.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Inadequate authorization controls
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improperly configured authorization policies can allow users to gain access to resources they should not have access to, potentially leading to data manipulation or leakage.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users or malicious insiders exploiting weak or misconfigured authorization policies to gain access to sensitive data or resources illegally.
Impacts
Data breach, unauthorized data modification, loss of data integrity, and potential legal and financial repercussions for failing to protect sensitive information.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker discovers a misconfiguration in AWS Cognito authorization policies that grant excessive permissions. By exploiting this, they access confidential customer data, modify records, and exfiltrate sensitive information, leading to significant harm to the organization's reputation and financial standing.

threat.name: Data exposure due to misconfigured tokens
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper management of tokens can lead to exposure of sensitive information.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
External attackers, malicious insiders, or compromised applications can intercept or misuse improperly managed tokens.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to user accounts, unauthorized actions within user contexts, and potential data breaches.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker intercepts a token transmitted over an insecure channel and uses it to gain unauthorized access to a user account. Alternatively, an insider with access to token storage leverages the token to perform unauthorized actions within the application.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

threat.name: Exposed user attributes
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improperly configured user attribute policies can lead to exposure of sensitive personal information.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors may exploit misconfigurations in user attribute policies to access, alter, or extract sensitive information stored within AWS Cognito.
Impacts
This can result in unauthorized access to PII (Personally Identifiable Information), leading to privacy violations, data breaches, and potential financial and reputational damage to the organization.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker discovers that email addresses and phone numbers are set to be publicly readable in the User Pool. By leveraging this misconfiguration, they can harvest this sensitive information for phishing attacks or identity theft. Another scenario might involve an insider modifying attribute policies to expose additional sensitive attributes without proper authorization.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1531 - Account Access Removal

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Insufficient session management
threat.desc:
General threat description
Poor session management can lead to session hijacking or replay attacks.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers can exploit poorly managed sessions, particularly if session identifiers are predictable, not rotated frequently, or not securely stored.
Impacts
Successful exploitation can result in unauthorized access to user accounts, data breaches, and potential financial loss, damaging the companyâ€™s reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker captures a user's session token through a man-in-the-middle attack or by accessing logs where tokens are stored improperly. The attacker then uses the token to impersonate the user and gain unauthorized access to sensitive resources.

threat.name: Compromised accounts due to poor multi-factor authentication (MFA)
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without multi-factor authentication (MFA), accounts become susceptible to unauthorized access if credentials are phished or otherwise compromised.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers can use phishing schemes, social engineering tactics, or exploit credential leaks from other breaches to gain access to an account.
Impacts
Unauthorized access can lead to data breaches, loss of sensitive information, and potentially damaging modifications or deletions of user data and application settings.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker successfully phishes an AWS Cognito user's credentials through a convincing email. Without MFA in place, the attacker uses the compromised credentials to log in and access the account, leading to unauthorized data access and potential exploitation of the user's information.

weakness.name: CWE-272
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-272: Least Privilege Violation The elevated privilege level required to perform operations such as chroot() should be dropped immediately after the operation is performed.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-532
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-532: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File Information written to log files can be of a sensitive nature and give valuable guidance to an attacker or expose sensitive user information.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Capture CloudWatch API activity with CloudTrail and secure S3 storage
countermeasure.desc:
Record every call to Amazon CloudWatch and CloudWatch Logs APIsâ€”whether it comes from the console, an SDK, or another AWS serviceâ€”by creating a multi-Region CloudTrail trail and delivering the events to a dedicated, protected Amazon S3 bucket. This preserves a tamper-evident audit log that security teams can query and retain long-term.

Implementation guidance

  1. Create or update the trail
    • In the CloudTrail console (or IaC), create a new organization or account trail and enable across all Regions so region-scoped CloudWatch actions are captured.
    • Log Management events â€“ Read + Write (these include every cloudwatch:* and logs:* API). No extra data-event selector is required.
  2. Deliver to a hardened S3 bucket
    • Choose or create a bucket in a log-archive account.
    • Block public access, disable ACLs, and add a bucket policy that:
    • {
       "Effect": "Deny",
       "Principal": "*",
       "Action": "s3:*",
       "Resource": ["arn:aws:s3:::cw-trail-logs/*", "arn:aws:s3:::cw-trail-logs"],
       "Condition": {"Bool": {"aws:SecureTransport": "false"}}
      }
    • Enable SSE-KMS encryption and versioning; turn on log file validation to detect tampering.
  3. Retention and analysis
    • Set an S3 lifecycle rule to transition older logs to Glacier Instant Retrieval or Deep Archive after your compliance retention window (e.g., 90 days â†’ Glacier, delete after 7 years).
    • Optionally stream the trail to CloudWatch Logs or an Amazon Athena table for real-time alerting and ad-hoc queries.
  4. Guardrails & monitoring
    • Enable AWS Config rules such as cloudtrail-enabled and s3-bucket-public-read-prohibited to ensure the trail and bucket stay compliant.
    • Alert on StopLogging, DeleteTrail, or S3 policy changes via EventBridge â†’ SNS/ChatOps.
  5. Periodic review
    • Quarterly, verify that new Regions are still covered and that the KMS key policy allows only the logging account to encrypt/decrypt.
    • Re-run an integrity check with aws cloudtrail validate-logs during incident response exercises.

Implementing this control guarantees that every CloudWatch action is immutably logged and stored in a bucket that meets the principle of least privilege, supporting forensic analysis and regulatory retention.

references

  • Logging CloudWatch API and console operations with CloudTrail
  • CloudTrail security best practices

countermeasure.name: Continuously evaluate CloudWatch resources with Security Hub and AWS Config
countermeasure.desc:
Activate AWS Security Hub (AWS Foundational Security Best Practices or other relevant standards) and AWS Config to run compliance checks against every Amazon CloudWatch resourceâ€”log groups, alarms, dashboards, Contributor Insights rules, and metric filtersâ€”on a rolling basis:

  1. Turn on Security Hub in all Regions (or via AWS Organizations) and enable the standard that contains the CloudWatch controls (for example, CW_LOGS_1 â€“ Enable VPC Flow Logs alarms). Findings automatically surface when a log group, alarm, or metric filter violates the control.
  2. Enable AWS Config recording and deploy the â€œOperational Best Practices for Amazon CloudWatchâ€ conformance pack (or choose individual managed rules such as CLOUDWATCH_ALARM_ACTION_CHECK and CLOUDWATCH_LOG_GROUP_ENCRYPTED). These rules evaluate resource configuration at creation and on every drift event.
  3. Set up aggregation & alerting
    • Aggregate Security Hub findings to the delegated administrator account; forward high-severity CloudWatch findings to an SNS topic integrated with your ticketing/on-call system.
    • Use AWS Config aggregators or a central dashboard (Config History + Security Hub Insights) to view compliance trends across accounts and Regions.
  4. Automate remediation â€“ Attach EventBridge rules to specific finding types (e.g., missing encryption) that invoke an SSM Automation or Lambda function to apply the correct setting, then mark the finding RESOLVED.
  5. Governance & review
    • Include the conformance pack template and any custom Config rules in your IaC repository; fail CI/CD builds if they are removed.
    • Review rule parameters (log-group prefixes, alarm thresholds, required encryption keys, etc.) quarterly and update them as new CloudWatch features or compliance clauses appear.

By combining Security Hubâ€™s managed controls with AWS Configâ€™s rule engine, you gain continuous, standards-based assurance that CloudWatch is configured securely and remains compliant as your environment evolves.

references

  • Security Hub controls for CloudWatch
  • Operational Best Practices for Amazon CloudWatch

countermeasure.name: Encrypt CloudWatch logs at rest with customer-managed KMS keys
countermeasure.desc:
Secure every Amazon CloudWatch Logs log group by associating it with an AWS KMS customer-managed key (CMK) instead of relying on the default, AWS-owned key. A CMK lets you define your own rotation schedule, attach restrictive key policies, and audit every decrypt operation.

Implementation checklist

  1. Create or select a CMK
    • aws kms create-key --description "CloudWatch Logs CMK"
    • Enable automatic rotation (every 365 days) or schedule key rotation manually.
  2. Lock down the key policy
    • Add the CloudWatch Logs service principalâ€”logs.<region>.amazonaws.comâ€”with encrypt/decrypt permissions.
    • Optionally restrict use to the specific log-group ARN with an kms:EncryptionContext:aws:logs:arn condition.
  3. Associate the CMK with each log group
    • New groups: aws logs create-log-group --log-group-name /app/orders --kms-key-id <CMK-ARN>
    • Existing groups: aws logs associate-kms-key --log-group-name /app/orders --kms-key-id <CMK-ARN>
    • Update IaC templates (CloudFormation/Terraform) so encryption is declared at build time and drift-detection fails when no key is set.
  4. Verify encryption
    • aws logs describe-log-groups --log-group-name-prefix /app/orders --query "logGroups[*].kmsKeyId" should return the CMK ARN.
    • Run a sample PutLogEvents; confirm CloudTrail shows Decrypt events that reference the CMK.
  5. Monitor and rotate
    • Enable CloudWatch alarms on kms:Disabled or kms:ScheduleKeyDeletion events for the CMK.
    • Rotate or retire keys via a controlled change window; re-associate log groups with the new CMK before disabling the old one.
  6. Continuous compliance
    • Deploy the AWS Config rule cloudwatch-log-group-encrypted (or similar) and alert when a group lacks SSE-KMS.
    • Include a Security Hub/FSBP control to surface non-encrypted groups at the account level.

Following this procedure guarantees that all log data is encrypted with keys you control, meeting regulatory requirements for data confidentiality, key management, and separation of duties.

References

  • Encrypt log data in CloudWatch Logs using AWS Key Management Service
  • CloudWatch logs are not encrypted at rest using KMS CMKs

countermeasure.name: Enforce TLS 1.2+ and perfect forward secrecy for CloudWatch API communications
countermeasure.desc:
AWS CloudWatch endpoints already refuse TLS 1.0/1.1, but every client you manage must also negotiate TLS 1.2 or newer and present a cipher suite that offers perfect forward secrecy (PFS)â€”for example, any suite that starts with ECDHE_ or DHE_. This prevents downgrade attacks and meets AWSâ€™s minimum-encryption requirement.

Implementation checklist

  1. Update runtimes and libraries
    • OpenSSL â‰¥ 1.1.1, Java 8 u181+, .NET 4.6+, AWS CLI v2, and current AWS SDK releases all default to TLS 1.2.
    • In base images or AMIs, set MinProtocol = TLSv1.2 (OpenSSL) or equivalent.
  2. Disable legacy protocols and weak suites
    • Web proxies or forwarders: ssl_protocols TLSv1.2 TLSv1.3; ssl_prefer_server_ciphers off;.
    • Container or OS hardening scripts should strip TLSv1/TLSv1.1 and static-key suites (e.g., *_RSA_*).
  3. Add automated tests
    • CI step:
    • openssl s_client -connect monitoring.${AWS_REGION}.amazonaws.com:443 -tls1_1 && \
       { echo "âŒ TLS 1.1 still accepted"; exit 1; } || echo "âœ… TLS 1.1 correctly rejected"
    • Repeat with -tls1_2; the handshake must succeed.
  4. Secure interface VPC endpoints
    • Allow only TCP 443 in the endpointâ€™s security group.
    • Inspect flow logs for any TLSv1/TLSv1.1 attempts and alert if they appear.
  5. Centralize enforcement
    • In AWS Organizations, attach an SCP that denies cloudwatch:* when aws:SecureTransport is false.
    • Deploy an AWS Config custom rule or linter that fails images containing TLSv1/TLSv1.1.
  6. Continuous monitoring & patching
    • Run AWS Inspector or OS vulnerability scans monthly; rebuild AMIs/containers when OpenSSL or Java receives critical CVEs.
    • Review cipher-suite telemetry and rotate certificates if you retire old CAs.

Properly enforcing modern TLS with PFS ensures CloudWatch telemetry stays confidential and resistant to future key compromise.

References

  • Infrastructure security for CloudWatch
  • TLS 1.2 to become the minimum protocol level for all AWS service API endpoints

countermeasure.name: Grant least-privilege CloudWatch access with IAM roles, permission boundaries, and key rotation
countermeasure.desc:
Provision every workload and human operator with only the CloudWatch actions it truly needs, delivered through temporary credentials, and ring-fence those permissions with a boundary policy:

  1. Design fine-grained policies
    • List the exact actions the principal needs (for example, logs:PutLogEvents, logs:CreateLogStream, cloudwatch:PutMetricData).
    • Scope resources precisely (arn:aws:logs:eu-west-1:123456789012:log-group:/aws/lambda/orders:*) andâ€”where supportedâ€”add aws:ResourceTag or logs:LogGroupName conditions to prevent horizontal sprawl.
  2. Use roles, not long-term IAM users
    • Attach policies to service roles (EC2 instance profiles, Lambda execution roles, ECS task roles) or to federated/SSO roles for humans.
    • Disable or avoid creating IAM users altogether; they require permanent access keys.
  3. Enforce permission boundaries
    • Create an account-wide managed policy that defines the absolute maximum CloudWatch scope (for example, deny wildcard logs:* or actions outside approved Regions).
    • Attach this policy as a permissions boundary to every role so even misconfigured inline or attached policies cannot exceed it.
  4. Rotate credentials automatically
    • Where access keys are still unavoidable (build agents, legacy scripts), store them in AWS Secrets Manager and rotate on a 90-day schedule with a Lambda function or the IAM credential-report alarm.
    • Enable AWS Config rule iam-user-unused-credentials-check and alert if a key is older than the defined window or unused for 45 days.
  5. Validate continuously
    • Run IAM Access Analyzer to surface unintended CloudWatch permissions.
    • Add a CI/CD linter that fails commits introducing logs:* or cloudwatch:* wildcard privileges.
    • Stream CloudTrail events to Security Hub and raise findings on PutUserPolicy, AttachRolePolicy, or CreateAccessKey that violate the guardrails.
  6. Review regularly
    • Quarterly, prune unused log groups and metrics, then tighten policies accordingly.
    • Re-evaluate the boundary policy as new CloudWatch features (e.g., Logs Insights, cross-account metrics) are adopted.

Implementing least-privilege policies, permission boundaries, and automatic key rotation ensures CloudWatch can collect the telemetry you need without giving principals the power to tamper with, exfiltrate, or overload log and metric data.

References

  • IAM policy examples for CloudWatch Logs
  • Permissions boundaries for IAM entities

countermeasure.name: Mask sensitive data in CloudWatch Logs and keep credentials out of logs
countermeasure.desc:
Protect log integrity and privacy by enabling CloudWatch Logs data-protection masking on every log group and by ensuring that no secrets or personally identifiable information (PII) are written to log messages, metric dimensions, or resource tags.

Implementation steps

  1. Attach a data-protection policy to each log group (or at the account level).
    • In the console: Logs â†’ Log groups â†’ Actions â†’ Create data protection policy.
    • Choose relevant managed data identifiers (credit-card numbers, email addresses, access keys, etc.) or add custom regex patterns.
    • Select the De-identify (mask) action so matching substrings are automatically replaced with placeholders.
  2. Block credentials and PII at the source.
    • Review application logging code; exclude secrets, access tokens, or user data from log payloads.
    • Never place sensitive values in CloudWatch metric dimensions, logâ€group names, or tag keys/valuesâ€”these fields are not run through the masking engine.
  3. Test and validate before production.
    • Send sample events containing fake identifiers; confirm they appear masked in the console and when fetched with filter-log-events.
    • Enable the Audit action in the policy to emit CloudWatch metrics (DataProtectionFindings) and create alarms on unmasked detections.
  4. Automate enforcement with IaC and guardrails.
    • Store policy JSON in Terraform/CloudFormation modules; fail the pipeline if a new log group lacks the standard policy.
    • Add AWS Config custom rules that flag metric or tag values matching forbidden patterns (for example, AKIA[0-9A-Z]{16}).
  5. Review quarterly.
    • Update the list of data identifiers as regulations evolve (GDPR, PCI DSS, HIPAA).
    • Inspect DataProtectionFindings metrics and Security Hub findings; remediate services still emitting unmasked data.

Following this control keeps secrets and PII out of your observability pipeline, satisfies compliance requirements, and reduces the risk of accidental data exposure in logs.

References

  • Help protect sensitive log data with masking
  • Understanding data protection policies in CloudWatch Logs

countermeasure.name: Require MFA for all identities and grant least-privilege access
countermeasure.desc:
Strengthen account-level security by enforcing multi-factor authentication (MFA) on every human identityâ€”root user, IAM users, and AWS IAM Identity Center (formerly AWS SSO) usersâ€”while granting each identity only the permissions it needs (principle of least privilege).

Implementation guidance

  1. Root user
    • Enable a hardware- or FIDO2-compliant MFA device on the root account immediately after account creation.
    • Lock the root credentials away; use them only for break-glass tasks such as account-level billing changes.
  2. IAM users (if still required)
    • Attach an IAM policy that denies * actions unless the session is authenticated with MFA ("Condition":{"Bool":{"aws:MultiFactorAuthPresent":"true"}}).
    • Enforce a strong password policy (minimum 14 characters, symbols, rotation) and disable long-lived access keys where possible.
  3. Prefer AWS IAM Identity Center (SSO)
    • Create users and groups in AWS IAM Identity Center or a connected IdP (Azure AD, Okta, etc.) instead of IAM users.
    • Assign permission sets that map to IAM roles with narrowly scoped policies (read-only, app-admin, billing-view, etc.).
    • Require MFA at the IdP level; Identity Center passes the MFA context to the temporary session.
  4. Least-privilege permission design
    • Start with AWS-managed or service-specific job-function policies as a baseline, then remove actions not required.
    • Use IAM Access Analyzer and last-accessed data to trim unused permissions regularly.
    • Apply service control policies (SCPs) in AWS Organizations to set account-wide guardrails (e.g., deny deleting CloudTrail, deny disabling MFA).
  5. Monitoring and enforcement
    • Enable AWS Config rules such as iam-user-mfa-enabled, root-account-mfa-enabled, and iam-password-policy.
    • Stream CloudTrail management events to an analytics platform; alert on DeleteVirtualMFADevice, DeactivateMFADevice, or policy changes that broaden permissions.
  6. Periodic review
    • Quarterly, audit all identities: verify MFA devices, rotate permission sets, and deactivate any unused IAM users.
    • Automate findings remediation with AWS Security Hub â†’ EventBridge â†’ Lambda to re-enable MFA or quarantine non-compliant users.

Following this control eliminates single-factor logins and minimizes blast radius by ensuring every human session is short-lived, strongly authenticated, and scoped to the minimum set of allowed actions.

References

  • Enable MFA for the root user and IAM users
  • IAM security best practices

countermeasure.name: Restrict CloudWatch VPC endpoints using IAM resource policies
countermeasure.desc:
Create a custom IAM resource policy for every interface VPC endpoint that your workloads use to send metrics or logs to Amazon CloudWatch / CloudWatch Logs. The policy must:

  • Allow only the actions each workload needs â€“ typically logs:PutLogEvents, logs:CreateLogStream, or cloudwatch:PutMetricData.
  • Restrict the callerâ€™s network origin by adding either
    • aws:SourceVpc = vpc-xxxxxxxx (all traffic must come from the named VPC), or
    • aws:SourceVpce = vpce-xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx (traffic must enter through the specific endpoint ID).

Example endpoint policy JSON

{
 "Version":"2012-10-17",
 "Statement":[
   {
     "Effect":"Allow",
     "Principal":"*",
     "Action":[
       "logs:PutLogEvents",
       "logs:CreateLogStream"
     ],
     "Resource":"*",
     "Condition":{
       "StringEquals":{
         "aws:SourceVpce":"vpce-0abc123def4567890"
       }
     }
   }
 ]
}

Attach a similar policy to each CloudWatch monitoring and logs endpoint; use aws:SourceVpc if the endpoint will be replaced regularly.

Implementation checklist

  1. Identify endpoints â€“ aws ec2 describe-vpc-endpoints --filters Name=service-name,Values=com.amazonaws.<region>.logs.
  2. Author the policy â€“ store the JSON in your IaC repo; parameterise the VPC or VPCE IDs.
  3. Attach the policy â€“ aws ec2 modify-vpc-endpoint-policy --vpc-endpoint-id vpce-â€¦ --policy-document file://policy.json.
  4. Validate â€“ from another VPC/endpoint, attempt a disallowed action and confirm it fails with 403 AccessDenied.
  5. Monitor & rotate â€“ enable CloudTrail data events for CloudWatch Logs; alert if a denied action or a request from an unexpected VPC occurs. Review policies whenever new logging agents or VPCs are introduced.

Using least-privilege resource policies on the endpoint itself prevents rogue traffic from other VPCs or compromised routes from writing logs or metrics, even if the IAM identity has permissions.

References

  • Using CloudWatch Logs with interface VPC endpoints
  • Control access to VPC endpoints with endpoint policies

countermeasure.name: Use PrivateLink interface endpoints for CloudWatch and CloudWatch Logs
countermeasure.desc:
Create interface VPC endpoints (AWS PrivateLink) for both Amazon CloudWatch (com.amazonaws.<region>.monitoring) and CloudWatch Logs (com.amazonaws.<region>.logs) so that all metrics and log-ingestion traffic stays on the AWS backbone and never traverses the public internet.

Implementation steps

  1. Subnet & AZ planning â€“ Pick at least two private subnets in different Availability Zones; the endpoint puts an elastic network interface (ENI) in each one.
  2. Provision the endpoints
  3. aws ec2 create-vpc-endpoint \
     --vpc-id vpc-1234abcd \
     --service-name com.amazonaws.eu-west-1.monitoring \
     --vpc-endpoint-type Interface \
     --subnet-ids subnet-a subnet-b \
     --security-group-ids sg-endpoints
    # Repeat for com.amazonaws.eu-west-1.logs
  4. Make sure Enable private DNS is turned on (default) so SDKs and agents resolve the service names to the endpoint ENIs automatically.
  5. Tighten the security group attached to the endpoint ENIsâ€”allow only TCP 443 from the CIDRs or security groups that host your producers (EC2, Lambda in VPC, containers).
  6. (Optional) attach an endpoint policy that limits actions such as cloudwatch:PutMetricData or logs:PutLogEvents and uses aws:SourceVpc/aws:SourceVpce conditions for extra defense-in-depth.
  7. Validate from a private instance:
    • dig monitoring.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com A should return a 10.x address (your ENI).
    • aws logs put-log-events â€¦ should succeed without an Internet gateway or NAT.
  8. Governance â€“ Add an AWS Config rule (managed or custom) that checks every account/Region for the presence of the two endpoints and alarms if missing. Share endpoints across spoke VPCs with AWS RAM instead of duplicating them.
  9. Monitor â€“ CloudWatch publishes metrics like InterfaceEndpointActiveConnections; set alarms for connection errors or throttling to detect misconfiguration or abuse.

By routing monitoring data entirely inside your VPC, you close an unnecessary egress path, reduce latency, and align with compliance mandates that forbid public-internet traffic for observability pipelines.

References

  • Using CloudWatch with interface VPC endpoints
  • Using CloudWatch Logs with interface VPC endpoints
