usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Credential compromise
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Credential compromise in AWS CloudWatch occurs when attackers obtain valid AWS credentials (access keys, session tokens, or IAM user passwords) that allow them to read, modify, or delete monitoring data, dashboards, alarms, and logs.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, and compromised automation roles.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Phishing or social engineering to harvest IAM user credentials.
    • Exploiting leaked keys in code repositories or configuration files.
    • Hijacking EC2 instance or Lambda role tokens via metadata API access.

Impacts

  • Data Exposure: Unauthorized users can view sensitive log and metric data.
  • Service Disruption: Attackers can disable alarms, delete dashboards, or purge log groups.
  • Stealthy Persistence: Malicious actors hide their activities by modifying retention settings or suppressing notifications.
  • Compliance Violations: Tampering with audit trails and alerts can breach regulatory requirements.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Phished Access Key Abuse: An attacker tricks an engineer into revealing AWS keys, then calls CloudWatchâ€™s DeleteAlarms and DeleteDashboards APIs to blind the operations team.
  2. Leaked Config Leak: A CI/CD pipeline inadvertently exposes CloudWatch IAM keys in a public commit; attackers use them to export VPC Flow Logs and exfiltrate network traffic data.
  3. Instance Metadata Exploit: Malware on an EC2 instance reads its attached roleâ€™s temporary credentials, then uses PutMetricData to inject falsified metrics and mask malicious activity.

threat.name: Excessive IAM permissions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Excessive IAM permissions occur when users, roles, or service accounts are granted more CloudWatch privileges than requiredâ€”often via overly broad policies or wildcard actionsâ€”enabling unauthorized operations across monitoring, logging, and alerting functions.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised IAM credentials, and errant automation scripts.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Assigning policies like cloudwatch:* or logs:* on * resources.
    • Wildcard principals ("Principal": "*") or overly permissive condition-less statements.
    • Service-linked roles with unchecked trust relationships.

Impacts

  • Data Tampering & Deletion: Attackers can delete log groups or metrics, erasing forensic evidence.
  • Alert Suppression: Overprivileged actors disable alarms or modify thresholds to hide incidents.
  • False Metrics Injection: Unauthorized use of PutMetricData can mask malicious activity or skew dashboards.
  • Compliance & Audit Failures: Unchecked changes to retention settings and alarms undermine audit trails and regulatory controls.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Log Erasure: A compromised automation role with logs:DeleteLogGroup permission removes critical application logs to cover tracks after a breach.
  2. Alarm Tampering: An insider granted cloudwatch:DisableAlarmActions silences highâ€‘severity alerts during an unauthorized infrastructure change, delaying detection.
  3. Metric Pollution: An attacker uses PutMetricData on production namespaces to inject misleading metrics, causing ops teams to chase false positives.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1212 - Exploitation for Credential Access

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Public network exposure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Public network exposure occurs when CloudWatch endpoints (APIs, agent ports, or log ingestion interfaces) are reachable over the Internet without network restrictions, allowing any external actor to interact with your monitoring services.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, automated scanners, and malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Scanning for and calling the CloudWatch Logs or Metrics API from the public Internet.
    • Misconfigured security groups or VPC settings that leave agent ports (e.g., the CloudWatch Agentâ€™s HTTP endpoint) open.
    • Exploiting default or missing endpoint access controls to push or pull data.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Data Ingestion: Attackers can inject falsified metrics or logs, corrupting dashboards and alerts.
  • Data Exfiltration: Public access to Logs APIs may let adversaries retrieve sensitive telemetry or application logs.
  • Cost Spikes: Malicious actors flood your CloudWatch with high-volume custom metrics or log entries, driving up usage fees.
  • Monitoring Disruption: Overloaded or tampered endpoints can degrade or disable your monitoring pipelines.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Bogus Metric Flood: An attacker discovers your open CloudWatch PutMetricData endpoint and sends thousands of custom metrics per second, inflating costs and obscuring real alerts.
  2. Log Data Harvesting: Without VPC restrictions, a malicious user calls FilterLogEvents on critical log groups, extracting PII or credentials from application logs.
  3. Agent Endpoint Abuse: A misconfigured CloudWatch Agent on EC2 listens publicly; an attacker posts large log payloads to its HTTP listener, saturating instance CPU and network.

threat.name: No encryption in transit
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When CloudWatch trafficâ€”such as agentâ€‘toâ€‘CloudWatch logs, metric submissions, or crossâ€‘region stream replicationâ€”is sent without TLS, all data in flight is exposed to interception and manipulation.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Network eavesdroppers, MITM attackers, malicious insiders
  • Vectors: Sniffing unencrypted HTTP calls from CloudWatch agents; intercepting nonâ€‘TLS API requests; exploiting misconfigured SDKs that disable SSL

Impacts

  • Data Exposure: Sensitive logs and metric payloads (PII, credentials) can be harvested
  • Data Tampering: Inâ€‘flight modification of metrics or alarms skews monitoring and hides real issues
  • Compliance Breach: Transmitting regulated data unencrypted violates standards like PCIâ€¯DSS or GDPR

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Agent Sniffing: An attacker on the same subnet captures unencrypted CloudWatch Logs HTTP requests, extracting application stack traces and secrets.
  2. MITM Metric Injection: A malicious gateway intercepts and alters CloudWatch metric submissions to suppress alerts about unauthorized activity.
  3. Replication Hijack: Crossâ€‘region log replication over plaintext is hijacked, diverting logs to an attackerâ€‘controlled endpoint for analysis.

threat.name: Sensitive data exposure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Sensitive data exposure in CloudWatch occurs when logs, metrics, or dashboard widgets inadvertently contain PII, credentials, or proprietary information and are accessible to unauthorized parties due to misconfiguration or overly broad access.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised IAM principals, and external attackers who gain read access.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Overly permissive CloudWatch Logs resource policies or IAM roles (logs:FilterLogEvents on *).
    • Debug or application logs that record sensitive fields (passwords, tokens, user data).
    • Uncontrolled export of logs to S3 buckets without proper bucket policies.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Exposure of customer PII, credentials, or proprietary business data.
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of regulations like GDPR, HIPAA, or PCIâ€¯DSS.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of customer trust and potential legal liability.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Logs Policy Overexposure: A wildcard IAM policy grants all users logs:GetLogEvents on critical log groups; an attacker enumerates and downloads entries containing API keys.
  2. Debug Logging Leak: A misconfigured application writes full credit-card numbers to CloudWatch Logs; any user with log-read permissions can harvest them.
  3. Unprotected S3 Export: Automated CloudWatch Logs export to an S3 bucket lacks encryption and publicâ€‘access blocks, allowing anyone with the bucket URL to download sensitive audit trails.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1592 - Gather Victim Host Information

threat.name: Endpoint policy misconfiguration
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When CloudWatch endpoint policies are too permissive or misâ€‘scoped, unintended principals or networks can access or modify Logs, Metrics, or Alarmsâ€”effectively bypassing intended security boundaries.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, compromised AWS accounts
  • Attack Vectors:
    • VPC Endpoint policies using "Principal": "*", granting universal access
    • Missing aws:sourceVpce conditions, allowing unauthorized VPC or onâ€‘prem queries
    • Crossâ€‘account Logs policies (logs:GetLogEvents, logs:PutLogEvents) without proper scoping

Impacts

  • Data Exfiltration: Reading sensitive log data
  • Data Tampering: Injecting or overwriting metrics/logs
  • Boundary Bypass: Internal traffic routed without firewall inspection

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Open Principal Abuse: An attacker in another account uses a wildcardâ€‘principal VPC endpoint to flood your log groups with bogus entries, masking genuine alerts.
  2. Crossâ€‘Account Leak: A mis-scoped Logs policy lets an external AWS account pull your applicationâ€™s error logsâ€”including API keysâ€”for reconnaissance.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1531 - Account Access Removal

threat.name: Unencrypted data at rest
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unencrypted data at rest occurs when CloudWatch retains logs, metrics, or exported dashboards on disk or in S3 without encryption, leaving sensitive information exposed if storage is accessed by unauthorized parties.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised IAM principals, and external attackers who gain storage access.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Disabling or failing to configure CloudWatch Logsâ€“encryption keys (KMS).
    • Exporting logs to S3 buckets without SSE or bucketâ€‘level encryption.
    • Stealing EBS snapshots or backup files containing unencrypted metrics data.

Impacts

  • Data Exposure: PII, credentials, or proprietary information in logs can be read directly.
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of atâ€‘rest encryption mandates (e.g., GDPR, HIPAA, PCIâ€¯DSS).
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of trust if audit trails reveal sensitive customer or internal data.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. S3 Export Leak: An audit log export to an S3 bucket lacks SSEâ€‘KMS; an attacker with S3 read access downloads and harvests sensitive entries.
  2. Snapshot Theft: A malicious insider copies unencrypted EBS snapshots backing CloudWatch metrics storage, then mounts them elsewhere to inspect raw data.
  3. KMS Misconfiguration: CloudWatch Logs are left using the default AWSâ€‘managed key instead of a restricted CMK; after an account breach, an attacker decrypts archived logs to glean secrets.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1055.005 - Thread Local Storage

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of audit logging
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When CloudWatch fails to record administrative or dataâ€‘access eventsâ€”such as IAM changes, alarm modifications, or logâ€‘retrievalsâ€”thereâ€™s no trail of â€œwho did what,â€ making detection and investigation of malicious or accidental actions impossible.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised IAM principals, and automated malware.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Performing API calls (e.g. DeleteLogGroup, DisableAlarmActions) without corresponding CloudTrail or CloudWatch Logs entries.
    • Exploiting gaps in retention or delivery settings that drop audit events.
    • Leveraging direct SDK or CLI calls that bypass configured logging hooks.

Impacts

  • Delayed Detection: Unauthorized changes go unnoticed, extending dwell time.
  • Forensic Blind Spots: Incidents cannot be reconstructed, hindering rootâ€‘cause analysis.
  • Compliance Failures: Absence of required audit trails breaches standards like PCIâ€¯DSS, HIPAA, or SOCâ€¯2.
  • Persistent Threats: Attackers maintain covert access and alter settings without fear of discovery.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Stealthy Log Deletion: An attacker with delete rights removes critical log groups; without audit logs, thereâ€™s no record of who or what triggered the deletion.
  2. Alarm Suppression: A malicious actor disables highâ€‘severity alarms via the API; absent audit entries, onâ€‘call teams remain unaware of the suppression and miss critical alerts.
  3. Configuration Tampering: A compromised automation script updates metric thresholds to hide malicious activity; without changeâ€‘logs, the tampering is indistinguishable from legitimate updates.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Nonâ€‘compliance monitoring
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Nonâ€‘compliance monitoring occurs when CloudWatch isnâ€™t configured to track or alert on departures from security, operational, or regulatory policiesâ€”allowing violations (e.g., disabled encryption, open ports, expired certificates) to go undetected.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Negligent administrators, malicious insiders, and external attackers.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Failing to create CloudWatch Alarms for key compliance metrics (e.g., IAM policy changes, public S3 buckets).
    • Omitting EventBridge rules to capture CloudTrail nonâ€‘compliant events.
    • Not using Config rules or custom metrics for regulatory controls.

Impacts

  • Undetected Violations: Security misconfigurations and policy breaches persist unnoticed.
  • Regulatory Penalties: Failure to monitor compliance can lead to fines under standards like PCIâ€¯DSS, HIPAA, or GDPR.
  • Increased Attack Surface: Misconfigurations (e.g., exposed databases) remain open until manually discovered.
  • Reputational Damage: Extended nonâ€‘compliance erodes customer and stakeholder trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unmonitored Public Bucket: An S3 bucket holding PII is made public; without a CloudWatch Alarm on the â€œPublicAccessâ€ metric, the exposure isnâ€™t detected for days.
  2. Expired TLS Certificate: A load balancerâ€™s certificate expires; no metric or alarm is set for certificate age, causing encrypted traffic to fail without alert.
  3. IAM Policy Drift: An administrator grants AdministratorAccess to a user; absent an EventBridge rule to flag policy changes, the overâ€‘privileged account is created without notification.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1580 - Cloud Infrastructure Discovery

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-319

countermeasure.name: Enable automated image scanning for ECR repositories
countermeasure.desc:
To maintain a secure container environment in AWS ECR (Elastic Container Registry), configure automated image scans to detect vulnerabilities in container images upon push and on a regular schedule. This helps identify and mitigate potential security threats before deploying images.

Enable Image Scanning on Push:

  • In the AWS Management Console, navigate to your ECR repositories and enable the "Scan on Push" option. This setting ensures that each image is automatically scanned for vulnerabilities as soon as it is pushed to the repository.

Schedule Regular Image Scans:

  • Use AWS ECR's built-in capabilities to schedule periodic re-scans of all images. This is important for detecting newly discovered vulnerabilities in already stored images.

Set Up Notifications for Vulnerability Findings:

  • Configure Amazon SNS (Simple Notification Service) to send alerts for critical vulnerabilities detected in images. Integrate these notifications with your security information and event management (SIEM) tools or incident response workflows.

Review and Act on Scan Reports:

  • Regularly review vulnerability reports generated by ECR image scans. Prioritize remediation efforts for high and critical severity findings to minimize security risks.

Implement Automated Remediation Actions:

  • Integrate image scanning results with CI/CD pipelines to automatically block the deployment of images with high-severity vulnerabilities until they are resolved.

reference.name: Scan images for software vulnerabilities in Amazon ECR

countermeasure.name: Enable notifications for key ECR repository events
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security and monitoring of AWS ECR (Elastic Container Registry), configure ECR to send notifications for key repository events such as image push, pull, or deletion activities. This helps in promptly detecting unauthorized access or suspicious activities and allows for immediate response.

Set Up Amazon SNS for Notifications:

  • Create an Amazon Simple Notification Service (SNS) topic to handle notifications for ECR events. Ensure the SNS topic is configured to send alerts via email, SMS, or integrate with other monitoring tools as needed.

Configure ECR Event Rules:

  • In the AWS Management Console, navigate to the ECR service and set up event rules for important repository actions. Specify events such as image push, pull, and deletion activities to trigger notifications.

Integrate with CloudWatch Events:

  • Use Amazon CloudWatch Events to capture ECR repository events and route them to the SNS topic. This integration allows for real-time monitoring of repository activities and automated alerts.

Customize Notification Settings:

  • Tailor notification settings to match your organizationâ€™s security requirements. For example, set high-priority alerts for image deletions or pulls from unexpected IP addresses or regions.

countermeasure.name: Enforce HTTPS for all communications with ECR
countermeasure.desc:
To secure data in transit and prevent interception, ensure that all communications with AWS ECR (Elastic Container Registry) use HTTPS. This encrypts the data transferred between ECR and other services or clients, protecting it from eavesdropping and tampering by malicious actors.

Require HTTPS for ECR Endpoints:

  • Configure all client applications, scripts, and automation tools interacting with AWS ECR to use HTTPS endpoints (https://) rather than HTTP. This ensures that all API calls and data transfers are encrypted.

Enforce Secure Protocols:

  • Update all Docker clients and other tools that interact with ECR to support and use only secure protocols, ensuring compatibility with HTTPS. Avoid using outdated or insecure versions of Docker that do not enforce HTTPS.

Restrict Direct Internet Access:

  • For environments that do not require public internet access, use VPC endpoints (AWS PrivateLink) to connect to ECR securely without traversing the public internet. This further enhances the security of data in transit by keeping traffic within the AWS network.

Monitor Network Traffic for Compliance:

  • Use AWS CloudTrail and VPC Flow Logs to monitor network traffic and ensure that all communications with ECR repositories are using HTTPS. Set up alerts for any traffic detected over non-secure HTTP connections.

reference.name: Security in Amazon Elastic Container Registry

countermeasure.name: Implement lifecycle policies for automated image retention management
countermeasure.desc:
To maintain control over AWS ECR (Elastic Container Registry) repository contents and reduce the risk of accidental deletion, configure lifecycle policies to automate image retention management. This ensures that only relevant and necessary images are retained, optimizing storage and enhancing security.

Define Lifecycle Policies:

  • In the AWS Management Console, navigate to your ECR repository and create lifecycle policies to specify image retention rules. Define policies based on image tags, age, or count to ensure that older, unused, or untagged images are automatically removed.

Set Retention Criteria:

  • Establish criteria for retaining images, such as keeping only the latest versions, retaining images used in production, or keeping images for a specified period (e.g., 30 days). Ensure these criteria align with your organizationâ€™s deployment and security policies.

Apply Policies to Repositories:

  • Apply the defined lifecycle policies to all relevant ECR repositories to automate the cleanup process and prevent the accumulation of outdated or unused images.

Monitor and Adjust Policies:

  • Regularly review lifecycle policy logs and adjust policies as needed to accommodate changes in deployment practices, security requirements, or business needs.

Integrate with DevOps Workflows:

  • Ensure that lifecycle policies are integrated with your DevOps workflows to avoid unintentional removal of images required for CI/CD pipelines. Communicate policy details to development teams to align image usage with retention rules.

reference.name: Automate the cleanup of images by using lifecycle policies in Amazon ECR

countermeasure.name: Use resource-based policies to control access to ECR repositories
countermeasure.desc:
To secure AWS ECR (Elastic Container Registry) repositories, use resource-based policies to control access, ensuring that only authorized users and roles have the necessary permissions to interact with the repositories. This helps prevent unauthorized access and actions such as pulling, pushing, or deleting container images.

Define Resource-Based Policies:

  • In the AWS Management Console, navigate to the ECR service and create resource-based policies for each repository. These policies should specify who (users, roles, AWS accounts) can access the repository and what actions (e.g., push, pull, delete) they are allowed to perform.

Grant Least Privilege Access:

  • Configure the policies to follow the principle of least privilege, granting only the necessary permissions required for users or roles to perform their specific tasks. Avoid using overly broad permissions that could lead to unauthorized access.

Restrict Cross-Account Access:

  • If cross-account access is required, specify the exact AWS accounts and IAM roles that are allowed access to the ECR repository. Use conditions within the policy to restrict access based on specific criteria such as IP addresses or request time.

Apply and Review Policies Regularly:

  • Apply the resource-based policies to each ECR repository and regularly review them to ensure they align with the current security requirements and organizational policies. Update the policies as needed to accommodate changes in user roles or security needs.

Monitor Access and Usage:

  • Use AWS CloudTrail and Amazon CloudWatch to monitor access to ECR repositories and log all interactions. Set up alerts for any unauthorized access attempts or changes to repository settings.

reference.name: Private repository policies in Amazon ECR

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Insecure deletion of repository resources
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

"Insecure Deletion of Repository Resources" refers to the risk of accidental or malicious deletion of container images and repositories in AWS ECR (Elastic Container Registry) without proper authorization or safeguards. This could result in the loss of critical container images, disruption of application deployments, and potential security vulnerabilities.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, negligent administrators, external attackers with unauthorized access.
  • Vectors:
    • Misconfigured IAM policies allowing unauthorized or overly broad deletion permissions.
    • Lack of lifecycle policies or version control, leading to accidental deletions.
    • Exploitation of compromised credentials with deletion access.

Impacts:

  • Data Loss: Permanent deletion of critical container images, resulting in the inability to deploy or rollback applications.
  • Operational Disruption: Deletion of images can disrupt CI/CD pipelines, causing delays in application deployments and service outages.
  • Security Risks: Deletion of secure, trusted images could lead to the deployment of unvetted or compromised images.
  • Compliance Issues: Uncontrolled deletions may violate data retention policies or regulatory requirements.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Accidental Deletion: An administrator mistakenly deletes a repository containing critical images due to a lack of lifecycle management or version control, causing significant deployment issues.
  • Malicious Insider Action: A disgruntled employee with deletion access intentionally deletes key images from ECR, disrupting application deployments and causing potential security breaches.
  • Compromised Account: An attacker uses compromised credentials with deletion permissions to remove important images, leading to application downtime and security exposure.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Use of vulnerable container images
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

Using vulnerable container images in AWS ECR can expose applications to security risks. Vulnerabilities may come from outdated software, insecure dependencies, or malicious code within the images, allowing attackers to exploit these weaknesses.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, automated bots.
  • Vectors:
    • Pulling images from untrusted or public sources.
    • Deploying images without vulnerability scans.
    • Using outdated base images or insecure dependencies.

Impacts:

  • Security Breach: Exploitation of vulnerabilities to gain unauthorized access or execute malicious code.
  • Data Leakage: Unauthorized access to sensitive data within compromised containers.
  • Operational Disruption: Potential for Denial-of-Service (DoS) attacks or performance degradation.
  • Compliance Violations: Non-compliance with security regulations due to using unpatched images.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Outdated Image Exploit: An unpatched base image with a critical vulnerability is exploited, allowing an attacker to gain control over the container.
  • Malware in Unscanned Image: A container image containing malware is deployed without a security scan, leading to data exfiltration.
  • Insecure Dependencies: A container uses outdated libraries, which are exploited by attackers to access the backend database and steal sensitive data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1609 - Container Administration Command

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Insecure data transfer
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

"Insecure Data Transfer" refers to the risk of data being transmitted between AWS ECR and other services without adequate encryption. If data is transferred over insecure channels, it can be intercepted, modified, or stolen by malicious actors, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized access.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, unauthorized users.
  • Vectors:
    • Transmitting data between ECR and other services without using HTTPS.
    • Misconfigured network settings that allow unsecured communication.
    • Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks exploiting unencrypted traffic.

Impacts:

  • Data Breach: Interception of sensitive data in transit, such as container images, credentials, or configuration details.
  • Data Integrity Compromise: Modification of data during transfer, leading to corrupted or maliciously altered images.
  • Service Disruption: Potential for unauthorized access or manipulation of container images, impacting service availability.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Intercepted Credentials: An attacker intercepts unencrypted traffic between ECR and a client, capturing sensitive credentials used for authentication and gaining unauthorized access.
  • Man-in-the-Middle Attack: A MitM attack is executed on unsecured communications, allowing an attacker to modify container images in transit, injecting malicious code.
  • Unauthorized Access via Unsecured Connection: An insider exploits a misconfigured network setting to access and download sensitive images from ECR without proper authorization.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to ECR repositories
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

"Unauthorized Access to ECR Repositories" refers to the risk of unauthorized users gaining access to AWS ECR (Elastic Container Registry) repositories. This unauthorized access could lead to actions such as pulling, pushing, or deleting container images without proper authorization, potentially compromising the security and integrity of applications.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, unauthorized external users.
  • Vectors:
    • Misconfigured IAM policies or repository permissions allowing overly broad access.
    • Exploitation of compromised credentials with elevated privileges.
    • Inadequate use of resource-based policies, allowing unintended access.

Impacts:

  • Security Breach: Unauthorized users could pull sensitive or proprietary images, exposing them to external threats.
  • Data Manipulation: Attackers might push malicious images or delete critical images, leading to the deployment of compromised containers.
  • Operational Disruption: Deletion or tampering with images could disrupt application deployment pipelines, causing downtime.
  • Compliance Violations: Unauthorized access can lead to non-compliance with data protection and security standards.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Compromised Credentials: An attacker uses compromised credentials to access an ECR repository and pulls sensitive container images, exposing proprietary code or configurations.
  • Overly Permissive Policies: A repository is configured with overly permissive IAM policies that inadvertently grant public access, allowing unauthorized users to pull or push images without restriction.
  • Insider Threat: A malicious insider with unauthorized access to ECR repositories deletes critical images or replaces them with tampered versions, leading to potential security breaches and operational issues.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of monitoring of repository activities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

"Lack of Monitoring of Repository Activities" refers to the absence of adequate logging and monitoring for actions taken within AWS ECR repositories. Without proper monitoring, unauthorized access, suspicious activities, or potential security incidents such as unauthorized image pushes, pulls, or deletions may go undetected.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, negligent administrators.
  • Vectors:
    • Lack of configured logging for ECR repository actions.
    • No alerting mechanisms for critical events such as unauthorized access attempts or deletions.
    • Insufficient visibility into repository activities, leading to undetected malicious actions.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized Access: Lack of detection for unauthorized access attempts, potentially compromising repository security.
  • Data Loss: Undetected deletions or modifications of container images can lead to data loss or deployment of compromised images.
  • Compliance Violations: Failing to monitor repository activities may result in non-compliance with regulatory requirements.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Undetected Unauthorized Access: An external attacker gains unauthorized access to an ECR repository but remains undetected due to lack of monitoring, allowing for repeated unauthorized activities.
  • Malicious Insider Deletion: A disgruntled insider deletes critical images from the repository. Without monitoring, the action is not immediately noticed, causing operational disruptions.
  • Image Tampering: An attacker modifies images within the repository to inject malicious code. Due to insufficient monitoring, these changes go unnoticed until the compromised images are deployed.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1565.003 - Runtime Data Manipulation

weakness.name: CWE-1125
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1125: Excessive Attack Surface The product has an attack surface whose quantitative measurement exceeds a desirable maximum.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-276
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-276: Incorrect Default Permissions During installation, installed file permissions are set to allow anyone to modify those files.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-352
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-352: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) The web application does not, or can not, sufficiently verify whether a well-formed, valid, consistent request was intentionally provided by the user who submitted the request. When a web server is designed to receive a request from a client without any mechanism for verifying that it was intentionally sent, then it might be possible for an attacker to trick a client into making an unintentional request to the web server which will be treated as an authentic request. This can be done via a URL, image load, XMLHttpRequest, etc. and can result in exposure of data or unintended code execution.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Consider encryption of data at rest
countermeasure.desc:
You have the following options for protecting data at rest in Amazon S3:

  • Server-side encryption â€“ All Amazon S3 buckets have encryption configured by default, and all new objects that are uploaded to an S3 bucket are automatically encrypted at rest. Server-side encryption with Amazon S3 managed keys (SSE-S3) is the default encryption configuration for every bucket in Amazon S3. To use a different type of encryption, you can either specify the type of server-side encryption to use in your S3 PUT requests, or you can set the default encryption configuration in the destination bucket.

Amazon S3 also provides these server-side encryption options:

  • Server-side encryption with AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) keys (SSE-KMS)
  • Dual-layer server-side encryption with AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) keys (DSSE-KMS)
  • Server-side encryption with customer-provided keys (SSE-C)

For more information, see Protecting data with server-side encryption.

  • Client-side encryption â€“ Encrypt data client-side and upload the encrypted data to Amazon S3. In this case, you manage the encryption process, the encryption keys, and related tools. As with server-side encryption, client-side encryption can help reduce risk by encrypting the data with a key that is stored in a different mechanism than the mechanism that stores the data itself.

Amazon S3 provides multiple client-side encryption options. For more information, see Protecting data by using client-side encryption.

countermeasure.name: Consider using S3 Cross-Region Replication
countermeasure.desc:
Although Amazon S3 stores your data across multiple geographically diverse Availability Zones by default, compliance requirements might dictate that you store data at even greater distances. With S3 Cross-Region Replication (CRR), you can replicate data between distant AWS Regions to help satisfy these requirements. CRR enables automatic, asynchronous copying of objects across buckets in different AWS Regions. For more information, see Replicating objects.

Note

CRR requires both the source and destination S3 buckets to have versioning enabled.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-replication-enabled managed AWS Config rule.

countermeasure.name: Consider using S3 Object Lock
countermeasure.desc:
With S3 Object Lock, you can store objects by using a "Write Once Read Many" (WORM) model. S3 Object Lock can help prevent accidental or inappropriate deletion of data. For example, you can use S3 Object Lock to help protect your AWS CloudTrail logs.

For more information, see Using S3 Object Lock.

countermeasure.name: Disable access control lists (ACLs) and use bucket policies to manage permissions
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Object Ownership is an Amazon S3 bucket-level setting that you can use to control ownership of objects uploaded to your bucket and to disable or enable ACLs. By default, Object Ownership is set to the Bucket owner enforced setting and all ACLs are disabled. When ACLs are disabled, the bucket owner owns all the objects in the bucket and manages access to data exclusively using access management policies.

A majority of modern use cases in Amazon S3 no longer require the use of access control lists (ACLs). We recommend that you disable ACLs, except in unusual circumstances where you must control access for each object individually. To disable ACLs and take ownership of every object in your bucket, apply the bucket owner enforced setting for S3 Object Ownership. When you disable ACLs, you can easily maintain a bucket with objects uploaded by different AWS accounts.

When ACLs are disabled access control for your data is based on policies, such as the following:

  • AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) user policies
  • S3 bucket policies
  • Virtual private cloud (VPC) endpoint policies
  • AWS Organizations service control policies (SCPs)

Disabling ACLs simplifies permissions management and auditing. ACLs are disabled for new buckets by default. You can also disable ACLs for existing buckets. If you have an existing bucket that already has objects in it, after you disable ACLs, the object and bucket ACLs are no longer part of the access-evaluation process. Instead, access is granted or denied on the basis of policies.

Before you disable ACLs, make sure that you do the following:

  • Review your bucket policy to ensure that it covers all the ways that you intend to grant access to your bucket outside of your account.
  • Reset your bucket ACL to the default (full control to the bucket owner).

After you disable ACLs, the following behaviors occur:

  • Your bucket accepts only PUT requests that do not specify an ACL or PUT requests with bucket owner full control ACLs. These ACLs include the bucket-owner-full-control canned ACL or equivalent forms of this ACL that are expressed in XML.
  • Existing applications that support bucket owner full control ACLs see no impact.
  • PUT requests that contain other ACLs (for example, custom grants to certain AWS accounts) fail and return an HTTP status code 400 (Bad Request) with the error code AccessControlListNotSupported.

For more information, see Controlling ownership of objects and disabling ACLs for your bucket.

countermeasure.name: Discover sensitive data by using Amazon Macie
countermeasure.desc:
Amazon Macie is a security service that discovers sensitive data by using machine learning and pattern matching. Macie provides visibility into data security risks, and enables automated protection against those risks. With Macie, you can automate the discovery and reporting of sensitive data in your Amazon S3 data estate to gain a better understanding of the data that your organization stores in S3.

To detect sensitive data with Macie, you can use built-in criteria and techniques that are designed to detect a large and growing list of sensitive data types for many countries and regions. These sensitive data types include multiple types of personally identifiable information (PII), financial data, and credentials data. You can also use custom criteria that you defineâ€”regular expressions that define text patterns to match and, optionally, character sequences and proximity rules that refine the results.

If Macie detects sensitive data in an S3 object, Macie generates a security finding to notify you. This finding provides information about the affected object, the types and number of occurrences of the sensitive data that Macie found, and additional details to help you investigate the affected S3 bucket and object. For more information, see the Amazon Macie User Guide.

countermeasure.name: Enable AWS Config
countermeasure.desc:
Several of the best practices listed in this topic suggest creating AWS Config rules. AWS Config helps you to assess, audit, and evaluate the configurations of your AWS resources. AWS Config monitors resource configurations so that you can evaluate the recorded configurations against the desired secure configurations. With AWS Config, you can do the following:

  • Review changes in configurations and relationships between AWS resources
  • Investigate detailed resource-configuration histories
  • Determine your overall compliance against the configurations specified in your internal guidelines

Using AWS Config can help you simplify compliance auditing, security analysis, change management, and operational troubleshooting. For more information, see Setting Up AWS Config with the Console in the AWS Config Developer Guide. When specifying the resource types to record, ensure that you include Amazon S3 resources.

Important

AWS Config managed rules only supports general purpose buckets when evaluating Amazon S3 resources. AWS Config doesnâ€™t record configuration changes for directory buckets. For more information, see AWS Config Managed Rules and List of AWS Config Managed Rules in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

For an example of how to use AWS Config, see How to Use AWS Config to Monitor for and Respond to Amazon S3 Buckets Allowing Public Access on the AWS Security Blog.

countermeasure.name: Enable S3 versioning
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Versioning is a means of keeping multiple variants of an object in the same bucket. You can use versioning to preserve, retrieve, and restore every version of every object stored in your bucket. With versioning, you can easily recover from both unintended user actions and application failures.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-versioning-enabled managed AWS Config rule.

For more information, see Using versioning in S3 buckets.

countermeasure.name: Enforce encryption of data in transit
countermeasure.desc:
You can use HTTPS (TLS) to help prevent potential attackers from eavesdropping on or manipulating network traffic by using person-in-the-middle or similar attacks. We recommend allowing only encrypted connections over HTTPS (TLS) by using the aws:SecureTransport condition in your Amazon S3 bucket policies.

Important

We recommend that your application not pin Amazon S3 TLS certificates as AWS doesnâ€™t support pinning of publicly-trusted certificates. S3 automatically renews certificates and renewal can happen any time before certificate expiry. Renewing a certificate generates a new public-private key pair. If youâ€™ve pinned an S3 certificate which has been recently renewed with a new public key, you wonâ€™t be able to connect to S3 until your application uses the new certificate.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-ssl-requests-only managed AWS Config rule.

countermeasure.name: Ensure that your Amazon S3 buckets use the correct policies and are not publicly accessible
countermeasure.desc:
Unless you explicitly require anyone on the internet to be able to read or write to your S3 bucket, make sure that your S3 bucket is not public. The following are some of the steps that you can take to block public access:

  • Use S3 Block Public Access. With S3 Block Public Access, you can easily set up centralized controls to limit public access to your Amazon S3 resources. These centralized controls are enforced regardless of how the resources are created. For more information, see Blocking public access to your Amazon S3 storage.
  • Identify Amazon S3 bucket policies that allow a wildcard identity such as "Principal": "*" (which effectively means "anyone"). Also look for policies that allow a wildcard action "*" (which effectively allows the user to perform any action in the Amazon S3 bucket).
  • Similarly, look for Amazon S3 bucket access control lists (ACLs) that provide read, write, or full-access to "Everyone" or "Any authenticated AWS user."
  • Use the ListBuckets API operation to scan all of your Amazon S3 buckets. Then use GetBucketAcl, GetBucketWebsite, and GetBucketPolicy to determine whether each bucket has compliant access controls and a compliant configuration.
  • Use AWS Trusted Advisor to inspect your Amazon S3 implementation.
  • Consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-public-read-prohibited and s3-bucket-public-write-prohibited managed AWS Config Rules.

For more information, see Identity and Access Management for Amazon S3.

countermeasure.name: Identify and audit all of your Amazon S3 buckets
countermeasure.desc:
Identification of your IT assets is a crucial aspect of governance and security. You need to have visibility of all your Amazon S3 resources to assess their security posture and take action on potential areas of weakness. To audit your resources, we recommend doing the following:

  • Use Tag Editor to identify and tag security-sensitive or audit-sensitive resources, then use those tags when you need to search for these resources. For more information, see Searching for Resources to Tag in the Tagging AWS Resources User Guide.
  • Use S3 Inventory to audit and report on the replication and encryption status of your objects for business, compliance, and regulatory needs. For more information, see Amazon S3 Inventory.
  • Create resource groups for your Amazon S3 resources. For more information, see What are resource groups? in the AWS Resource Groups User Guide.

countermeasure.name: Identify potential threats to your Amazon S3 buckets by using Amazon GuardDuty
countermeasure.desc: Amazon GuardDuty is a threat detection service that identifies potential threats to your accounts, containers, workloads, and the data within your AWS environment. By using machine learning (ML) models, and anomaly and threat detection capabilities, Amazon GuardDuty continuously monitors different data sources to identify and prioritize potential security risks and malicious activities in your environment. When you enable GuardDuty, it offers threat detection for foundational data sources that includes AWS CloudTrail management events, VPC flow logs, and DNS logs. To extend threat detection to data plane events in S3 buckets, you can enable the GuardDuty S3 Protection feature. This feature detects threats such as data exfiltration and suspicious access to S3 buckets via Tor nodes. GuardDuty also establishes a normal baseline pattern in your environment and when it identifies a potentially anomalous behavior, it provides contextual information to help you remediate the potentially compromised S3 bucket or AWS credentials. For more information, see GuardDuty.

countermeasure.name: Implement least privilege access
countermeasure.desc:
When granting permissions, you decide who is getting what permissions to which Amazon S3 resources. You enable specific actions that you want to allow on those resources. Therefore, we recommend that you grant only the permissions that are required to perform a task. Implementing least privilege access is fundamental in reducing security risk and the impact that could result from errors or malicious intent.

The following tools are available to implement least privilege access:

  • Policy actions for Amazon S3 and Permissions Boundaries for IAM Entities
  • How Amazon S3 works with IAM
  • Access control list (ACL) overview
  • Service Control Policies

For guidance on what to consider when choosing one or more of the preceding mechanisms, see Identity and Access Management for Amazon S3.

countermeasure.name: Implement monitoring by using AWS monitoring tools
countermeasure.desc:
Monitoring is an important part of maintaining the reliability, security, availability, and performance of Amazon S3 and your AWS solutions. AWS provides several tools and services to help you monitor Amazon S3 and your other AWS services. For example, you can monitor Amazon CloudWatch metrics for Amazon S3, particularly the PutRequests, GetRequests, 4xxErrors, and DeleteRequests metrics. For more information, see Monitoring metrics with Amazon CloudWatch and Monitoring Amazon S3.

For a second example, see Example: Amazon S3 Bucket Activity. This example describes how to create a CloudWatch alarm that is triggered when an Amazon S3 API call is made to PUT or DELETE a bucket policy, a bucket lifecycle, or a bucket replication configuration, or to PUT a bucket ACL.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc:
AWS CloudTrail provides a record of actions taken by a user, a role, or an AWS service in Amazon S3. You can use information collected by CloudTrail to determine the following:

  • The request that was made to Amazon S3
  • The IP address from which the request was made
  • Who made the request
  • When the request was made
  • Additional details about the request

For example, you can identify CloudTrail entries for PUT actions that affect data access, in particular PutBucketAcl, PutObjectAcl, PutBucketPolicy, and PutBucketWebsite.

When you set up your AWS account, CloudTrail is enabled by default. You can view recent events in the CloudTrail console. To create an ongoing record of activity and events for your Amazon S3 buckets, you can create a trail in the CloudTrail console. For more information, see Logging data events in the AWS CloudTrail User Guide.

When you create a trail, you can configure CloudTrail to log data events. Data events are records of resource operations performed on or within a resource. In Amazon S3, data events record object-level API activity for individual buckets. CloudTrail supports a subset of Amazon S3 object-level API operations, such as GetObject, DeleteObject, and PutObject. For more information about how CloudTrail works with Amazon S3, see Logging Amazon S3 API calls using AWS CloudTrail. In the Amazon S3 console, you can also configure your S3 buckets to Enabling CloudTrail event logging for S3 buckets and objects.

AWS Config provides a managed rule (cloudtrail-s3-dataevents-enabled) that you can use to confirm that at least one CloudTrail trail is logging data events for your S3 buckets. For more information, see cloudtrail-s3-dataevents-enabled in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

countermeasure.name: Use IAM roles for applications and AWS services that require Amazon S3 access
countermeasure.desc:
In order for applications running on Amazon EC2 or other AWS services to access Amazon S3 resources, they must include valid AWS credentials in their AWS API requests. We recommend not storing AWS credentials directly in the application or Amazon EC2 instance. These are long-term credentials that are not automatically rotated and could have a significant business impact if they are compromised.

Instead, use an IAM role to manage temporary credentials for applications or services that need to access Amazon S3. When you use a role, you don't have to distribute long-term credentials (such as a username and password or access keys) to an Amazon EC2 instance or AWS service, such as AWS Lambda. The role supplies temporary permissions that applications can use when they make calls to other AWS resources.

For more information, see the following topics in the IAM User Guide:

  • IAM Roles
  • Common Scenarios for Roles: Users, Applications, and Services

countermeasure.name: Use S3 Storage Lens
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Storage Lens is a cloud-storage analytics feature that you can use to gain organization-wide visibility into object-storage usage and activity. S3 Storage Lens also analyzes metrics to deliver contextual recommendations that you can use to optimize storage costs and apply best practices for protecting your data.

With S3 Storage Lens, you can use metrics to generate summary insights, such as finding out how much storage you have across your entire organization or which are the fastest-growing buckets and prefixes. You can also use S3 Storage Lens metrics to identify cost-optimization opportunities, implement data-protection and access-management best practices, and improve the performance of application workloads.

For example, you can identify buckets that don't have S3 Lifecycle rules to abort incomplete multipart uploads that are more than 7 days old. You can also identify buckets that aren't following data-protection best practices, such as using S3 Replication or S3 Versioning. For more information, see Understanding Amazon S3 Storage Lens.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized extraction of sensitive data from S3 buckets
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Sensitive data stored in Amazon S3 buckets may be extracted without proper oversight due to inadequate monitoring and insufficient access controls. This can lead to unauthorized data access, leaks, and breaches, compromising the integrity and confidentiality of the data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include malicious insiders, external attackers, and compromised accounts. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak access controls, lack of encryption, and insufficient logging and monitoring mechanisms, allowing undetected data exfiltration.

Impacts

Impacts include severe data breaches, loss of intellectual property, financial losses, legal consequences due to non-compliance with data protection regulations, and damage to an organization's reputation and customer trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An insider with access to an S3 bucket containing sensitive customer information downloads the data without being detected due to a lack of proper monitoring and oversight.
  2. An external attacker compromises an employee's AWS credentials and uses them to extract sensitive data from an S3 bucket, leading to a significant data breach and regulatory fines.
  3. Sensitive financial data stored in an S3 bucket is exfiltrated by an attacker exploiting overly permissive access controls, resulting in the exposure of confidential business information and competitive disadvantage.
  4. A lack of proper logging and alerting mechanisms allows an attacker to continuously extract small amounts of sensitive data over an extended period, going unnoticed until the breach is discovered during an audit.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1011 - Exfiltration Over Other Network Medium

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Inadequate monitoring of S3 buckets
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

The lack of adequate monitoring of Amazon S3 buckets can result in undetected data breaches or data loss. Without proper logging, alerting, and monitoring mechanisms, unauthorized access or malicious activities can go unnoticed, leading to severe security and compliance issues.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers, malicious insiders, and compromised accounts. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak or non-existent monitoring systems, allowing attackers to access, modify, or extract data without detection.

Impacts

Impacts include significant data breaches, loss of sensitive and critical data, non-compliance with regulatory requirements, financial losses, and damage to the organization's reputation and customer trust. The inability to detect and respond to security incidents in a timely manner exacerbates these risks.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker gains unauthorized access to an S3 bucket and exfiltrates sensitive data over time. Due to inadequate monitoring, the breach remains undetected until the data is leaked or sold on the dark web, resulting in a major security incident.
  2. An insider with malicious intent deletes critical business data from an S3 bucket. Without proper monitoring and alerting mechanisms, the data loss is not identified until business operations are disrupted, causing significant financial and operational impacts.
  3. During a routine compliance audit, an organization discovers that an S3 bucket containing regulated data has been accessed by unauthorized users multiple times over the past year, leading to substantial fines and legal consequences.
  4. A lack of detailed logging and alerting allows an attacker to use compromised credentials to make unauthorized changes to an S3 bucket policy, granting themselves ongoing access and leading to a prolonged data breach that goes unnoticed for months.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Insecure S3 bucket configurations
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Amazon S3 buckets that are not properly secured may be accessible by unauthorized users. This can result from misconfigured permissions, lack of encryption, and absence of stringent access controls, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized data access.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers, malicious insiders, and automated bots scanning for misconfigured buckets. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak or incorrect bucket policies, overly permissive access controls, and publicly accessible buckets without proper security measures.

Impacts

Impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data breaches, loss of intellectual property, compliance violations, financial penalties, and damage to the organization's reputation. Misconfigured buckets can also lead to data manipulation or deletion, further compromising data integrity and availability.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An S3 bucket containing confidential customer data is mistakenly configured with public read access, allowing anyone on the internet to access and download sensitive information, resulting in a significant data breach.
  2. During a routine security scan, it is discovered that several S3 buckets are accessible to unauthorized internal users due to misconfigured IAM policies, leading to unauthorized access and potential data leaks.
  3. An external attacker uses automated tools to identify and access an S3 bucket that has been inadvertently left publicly accessible. The attacker exfiltrates proprietary business information, causing financial and reputational damage to the company.
  4. A developer unintentionally grants write permissions to all authenticated AWS users on an S3 bucket, allowing unauthorized users to upload malicious content or delete critical data, leading to operational disruptions and potential legal issues.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1526 - Cloud Service Discovery

component.desc: Business users interacting with the system.

weakness.name: CWE-1021
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1021: Improper Restriction of Rendered UI Layers or Frames The web application does not restrict or incorrectly restricts frame objects or UI layers that belong to another application or domain, which can lead to user confusion about which interface the user is interacting with. A web application is expected to place restrictions on whether it is allowed to be rendered within frames, iframes, objects, embed or applet elements. Without the restrictions, users can be tricked into interacting with the application when they were not intending to.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-346
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-346: Origin Validation Error The product does not properly verify that the source of data or communication is valid.

weakness.name: CWE-400
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource, thereby enabling an actor to influence the amount of resources consumed, eventually leading to the exhaustion of available resources.

weakness.name: CWE-770
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-770: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling The product allocates a reusable resource or group of resources on behalf of an actor without imposing any restrictions on the size or number of resources that can be allocated, in violation of the intended security policy for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-79
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-79: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting') The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes user-controllable input before it is placed in output that is used as a web page that is served to other users.

countermeasure.name: Implement frame busting techniques
countermeasure.desc:
Frame busting is a technique used to prevent a website from being displayed within a frame or iframe of another site. This is crucial to thwart clickjacking attacks, where an attacker might use a frame to overlay deceptive elements over your UI, misleading users into performing unintended actions.

Use the X-Frame-Options HTTP Header

  • Implement the X-Frame-Options HTTP header in your web server's configuration or within your application's response headers.
  • Set this header to DENY to prevent any domain from framing your content.
  • Alternatively, use SAMEORIGIN if you need to allow framing of your content by the same domain.
  • Example for Apache server in .htaccess: Header always set X-Frame-Options "SAMEORIGIN"

Leverage Content Security Policy (CSP)

  • Enhance security by implementing the Content Security Policy header with the frame-ancestors directive.
  • Specify which domains are allowed to frame your siteâ€™s content. To disallow all framing, you can set it to 'none'.
  • Example CSP implementation: Header set Content-Security-Policy "frame-ancestors 'self';"

Employ Frame Busting Scripts

  • While headers are your first line of defense, add a JavaScript frame-busting script for additional protection.
  • Add the following script to your HTML documents to ensure they cannot be framed: 

if (top !== window) {
 top.location = window.location;
}

Regularly Update and Test

  • Regularly update your security configurations to cope with evolving threats.
  • Test your implementation across different browsers and devices to ensure that your site cannot be framed maliciously.

Additional Considerations:

  • Always validate your CSP and frame busting implementations using tools like browsersâ€™ developer tools to ensure they are working as expected.
  • Keep informed about new security practices and potential bypasses to frame busting techniques.

By following these steps, you can significantly enhance the security of your application's user interface against framing attacks, providing a safer environment for your users.

reference.name: OWASP Clickjacking Defense Cheat Sheet

countermeasure.name: Implement input validation and sanitization
countermeasure.desc:
Input validation and sanitization are crucial for preventing various forms of attacks, such as SQL injection, cross-site scripting (XSS), and command injection. Validation involves verifying whether the input meets the expected format and is within allowable limits. Sanitization involves cleaning the input to ensure that it is safe to handle.

Validate Input Strictly

  • Define the allowed types, patterns, and ranges for all user inputs based on your application's requirements.
  • Use regular expressions to enforce patterns such as email addresses, phone numbers, or user IDs.
  • Reject any input that does not strictly conform to these criteria.
  • Example in Python for an email input: 

import re
def validate_email(email):
   if not re.match(r"[^@]+@[^@]+\.[^@]+", email):
       raise ValueError("Invalid email format")


Sanitize Inputs Before Processing

  • Sanitize inputs by removing or encoding potentially harmful characters, especially when the input is incorporated into web pages or database queries.
  • Utilize libraries or frameworks that automatically handle sanitization, like OWASP Java Encoder for Java applications, or context-aware escaping functions in template engines.
  • Example using Python for web output:

from html import escape
def sanitize_html(input_string):
   return escape(input_string)
 

Use Parameterized Queries for Database Access

  • Avoid SQL injection by using parameterized queries or prepared statements instead of concatenating strings to form SQL commands.
  • Example using Python with SQLite:

import sqlite3
connection = sqlite3.connect('example.db')
cursor = connection.cursor()
cursor.execute("INSERT INTO Users (username) VALUES (?)", (username,))
connection.commit()
connection.close()
 

Apply Security Controls Framework-Wide

  • Ensure that validation and sanitization are consistently applied across all parts of the application that accept user input.
  • Consider using security-focused libraries and frameworks that encourage or enforce good security practices.

Test and Monitor

  • Regularly test your input validation and sanitization measures with both automated tools and manual testing to uncover any potential bypasses or flaws.
  • Monitor application logs for unusual activities that might indicate attempts to exploit input validation weaknesses.

Additional Considerations:

  • Keep abreast of the latest security advisories and updates related to the libraries and frameworks you use.
  • Educate developers about the importance of input validation and sanitization through code reviews and security training sessions.

Implementing thorough input validation and sanitization as described will help protect your application from common vulnerabilities and attacks, ensuring a more secure environment for your users and your data.

reference.name: OWASP Enterprise Security API (ESAPI)

countermeasure.name: Implement rate limiting
countermeasure.desc:
Rate limiting is crucial for protecting your application from abuse, such as denial-of-service attacks, brute force login attempts, and other types of misuse that could overwhelm your system. It involves restricting the number of requests a user can make to a particular endpoint within a specified time frame.

Define Rate Limits Based on Use Case

  • Assess the typical usage patterns of your application to establish reasonable limits.
  • Set different rate limits for different types of endpoints; for example, more sensitive actions like password changes might have stricter limits compared to more benign actions like viewing content.

Choose a Rate Limiting Strategy

  • Fixed window: Use a consistent time window (e.g., per minute, per hour) and allow a maximum number of requests in that window.
  • Sliding window log: Implement a more flexible approach where the window slides with the incoming requests, providing a smoother limit.
  • Token bucket: Allow bursts of requests but limit the overall rate over time.
  • Leaky bucket: Process requests at a steady rate and buffer bursts to prevent system overload.

Implement Rate Limiting Mechanism

  • Utilize middleware in web frameworks that support rate limiting. For example, for Node.js applications using Express, you can use libraries like express-rate-limit.
  • Example implementation in Express.js:

const rateLimit = require("express-rate-limit");

const limiter = rateLimit({
 windowMs: 15 * 60 * 1000, // 15 minutes
 max: 100, // limit each IP to 100 requests per windowMs
});

// Apply to all requests
app.use(limiter);
 

Store Rate Limiting Data

  • Decide on a storage solution for rate limiting counters, such as Redis, which can handle expiration and distribution efficiently.
  • Ensure that your storage choice can scale and perform under high load, which is critical for high-traffic applications.

Communicate Limits to Users

  • Include headers in HTTP responses to inform users of their current rate limit status, such as X-RateLimit-Limit, X-RateLimit-Remaining, and X-RateLimit-Reset.
  • Implement clear messaging on your frontend to alert users when they are approaching or have exceeded their rate limit.

Monitor and Adjust Limits

  • Regularly review the effectiveness of your rate limits. Adjust them based on new usage patterns or feedback from legitimate users who might be impacted.
  • Monitor logs for patterns indicating systematic abuse, and adjust your strategy as needed.

Additional Considerations:

  • Consider implementing IP whitelisting and blacklisting to more finely control access based on the user's behavior history.
  • Be mindful of implementing rate limiting in a way that doesnâ€™t inadvertently block or degrade service for legitimate users, particularly those coming from shared IP addresses like those in corporate or educational environments.

Implementing rate limiting as outlined will help ensure that your application can handle traffic efficiently and safely, protecting both the system and its users from abuse.

reference.name: OWASP REST Security Cheat Sheet

countermeasure.name: Implement visual cues and indicators
countermeasure.desc:
Visual cues and indicators enhance the usability and security of your application by providing feedback or warnings to users about their interactions or system states. These can include changes in button colors when active, spinner icons during loading phases, or warning messages for potentially insecure actions.

Design Clear and Intuitive Cues

  • Develop a consistent visual language that aligns with your application's design guidelines.
  • Use color, shape, animation, and positioning strategically to draw attention without overwhelming the user.
  • Example: Use a red color for warnings, green for successful actions, and yellow for caution.

Implement Feedback for Interactive Elements

  • Provide immediate feedback for user actions. For example, change the appearance of a button when hovered or clicked.
  • Use animations to indicate loading or processing states, which helps users understand that the application is active and responsive.
  • Example CSS for a button:

.button {
 background-color: #4CAF50; /* Green */
 border: none;
 color: white;
 padding: 15px 32px;
 text-align: center;
 text-decoration: none;
 display: inline-block;
 font-size: 16px;
 margin: 4px 2px;
 cursor: pointer;
 transition: background-color 0.3s ease;
}

.button:hover {
 background-color: #45a049;
}
 

Use Indicators for System Status

  • Indicate system or process statuses clearly, such as online/offline modes, connection issues, or security states.
  • Implement a visual indicator for secure sessions (e.g., a padlock icon when a connection is secured with SSL/TLS).
  • Example in HTML: <div id="status" class="status-offline">Offline</div>

Provide Contextual Help and Tooltips

  • Integrate tooltips or help icons next to complex features or inputs that require explanation.
  • Ensure tooltips are accessible on all devices, including mobile and those used by individuals with disabilities.
  • Example HTML for a tooltip: <a href="#" data-tooltip="Enter your email here. We do not share your email with anyone.">Email:</a>

Test for Clarity and Effectiveness

  • Conduct usability testing to gauge the effectiveness of your visual cues and indicators.
  • Gather user feedback to refine and adjust the visual elements to ensure they are understood and appreciated by users.

Ensure Accessibility

  • Make sure that all visual cues are accessible, including to those with visual impairments or color blindness.
  • Use text labels or ARIA labels in addition to color-based cues.

Additional Considerations:

  • Keep in mind that not all users interpret colors and icons the same way; cultural differences can influence user perception.
  • Regularly update visual elements to stay in line with modern UI/UX trends and standards.

By implementing visual cues and indicators as described, you can significantly enhance user interaction and security awareness within your application, providing a more engaging and safe experience.

reference.name: OWASP UI Redressing (Clickjacking) Cheat Sheet
