countermeasure.name: Use content security policy (CSP)
countermeasure.desc:
A Content Security Policy (CSP) is a security layer used to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. CSP works by specifying which sources the browser should allow to load resources from, thereby preventing malicious scripts from executing if they violate the specified policy.

Define Your CSP Strategy

  • Decide what kind of resources you want to restrict, such as scripts, stylesheets, images, frames, and more.
  • Identify the domains that your application should accept as valid sources for these resources.

Implement CSP via HTTP Headers

  • Configure your web server to send the Content-Security-Policy HTTP header.
  • Start with a restrictive policy and gradually allow specific domains and resources as needed.
  • Example strict CSP header: Content-Security-Policy: default-src 'self'; script-src 'self' https://apis.example.com; connect-src 'self'; img-src 'self' https://images.example.com;

Test CSP Implementation

  • Deploy the CSP in a testing environment.
  • Use tools like Google Chrome's Developer Tools to monitor CSP violations, which will be reported in the console.
  • Adjust the policy based on the results, allowing additional sources as necessary or tightening restrictions if feasible.

Use Nonce or Hash Values for Inline Scripts and Styles

  • If you must use inline scripts or styles, incorporate nonces (a random number that can only be used once) or hashes to whitelist specific scripts or styles.
  • Modify your CSP policy to include the nonce or hash: script-src 'nonce-2726c7f26c' 'strict-dynamic'; style-src 'sha256-x+y+z/';
  • Update your HTML to use the nonce or correct hash values:

<script nonce="2726c7f26c">
 console.log('This script runs because it matches the nonce in the CSP header.');
</script>


Handle CSP Violation Reports

  • Consider implementing a CSP report-uri directive to receive reports of policy violations.
  • Analyze violation data to improve policy enforcement and adjust your CSP settings accordingly.
  • Example of adding a report-uri: Content-Security-Policy: default-src 'self'; report-uri /csp-violation-report-endpoint;

Regularly Review and Update Your CSP

  • Regularly review the effectiveness of your CSP and update it as your web application evolves or as new threats emerge.
  • Stay informed about CSP best practices and updates in web standards.

Additional Considerations:

  • Be cautious with the use of the 'unsafe-inline' and 'unsafe-eval' directives as they can weaken your CSP significantly.
  • Educate your development team about the importance of adhering to the CSP, especially when adding new resources or third-party services to your application.

By implementing a CSP, you significantly enhance your application's security posture against common web vulnerabilities, helping to ensure that your content is not misused or maliciously exploited.

reference.name: MDN Web Docs - Content Security Policy

countermeasure.name: Use load balancing and scaling
countermeasure.desc:
Load balancing is the process of distributing network or application traffic across multiple servers to ensure no single server bears too much demand. This enhances the responsiveness and availability of applications. Scaling, on the other hand, involves adjusting the number of resourcesâ€”servers, instances, or containersâ€”to meet varying load levels, which can be done manually or automatically.

Choose the Right Type of Load Balancer

  • Identify the type of load balancer that suits your needs: hardware-based, software-based, or cloud-native.
  • Consider using Application Load Balancers for HTTP/HTTPS traffic or Network Load Balancers for TCP/UDP/SCTP traffic if you are in a cloud environment.

Implement Load Balancing

  • Configure a load balancer in front of your server pool. This can be done via hardware devices, software solutions, or services provided by cloud providers.
  • Set up health checks to ensure traffic is only sent to servers that are online and ready to handle requests.
  • Example setup using AWS Elastic Load Balancing: 

Create an Application Load Balancer, define the listening port, and attach it to a target group associated with your EC2 instances.
 

Implement Scaling Policies

  • Decide between manual scaling (where you adjust resources as needed) and auto-scaling (where adjustments are made automatically based on traffic).
  • Set up auto-scaling using cloud services or platform-specific tools to handle increases or decreases in load dynamically.
  • Example using AWS Auto Scaling: 

Define auto-scaling groups and policies based on CPU utilization or other performance metrics to automatically add or remove EC2 instances.
 

Test Your Implementation

  • Simulate traffic loads to validate that the load balancer correctly distributes traffic across your server environment.
  • Test scaling policies by artificially generating spikes in traffic and observing the response.

Monitor and Optimize

  • Continuously monitor the performance of your load balancers and the health of servers.
  • Use analytics and monitoring tools to track load patterns and scaling events, adjusting policies and configurations as necessary.

Ensure Security

  • Implement security measures such as SSL/TLS termination at the load balancer if it supports it, to offload processing from backend servers.
  • Regularly update and patch your load balancers and ensure that security configurations are enforced.

Document and Maintain Your Setup

  • Keep detailed documentation of your load balancing configurations and scaling policies.
  • Regularly review and update your setup in response to infrastructure changes, application updates, or shifts in traffic patterns.

Additional Considerations:

  • Load balancing and scaling not only enhance performance and availability but also contribute to fault tolerance. By distributing traffic and resources, you mitigate the impact of individual server failures.
  • Be aware of the costs associated with scaling, especially in cloud environments where costs can vary widely based on the number and type of resources utilized.

By effectively implementing load balancing and scaling strategies, you ensure that your application can handle varying loads efficiently while maintaining high availability and performance.

reference.name: OWASP Denial of Service Cheat Sheet

countermeasure.name: Use multi-factor authentication
countermeasure.desc:
Multi-factor authentication enhances security by requiring users to provide two or more verification factors to gain access to a resource, such as an application, online account, or a VPN. This significantly reduces the risk of unauthorized access resulting from compromised credentials.

Determine Appropriate Factors

  • Select the types of authentication factors you will use. Common factors include:
    1. Something you know (e.g., password or PIN)
    2. Something you have (e.g., security token, smartphone app, or smart card)
    3. Something you are (e.g., biometrics like fingerprints or facial recognition)

Choose an MFA Solution

  • Evaluate and choose an MFA solution that fits your security requirements and budget. Consider solutions from vendors like Google Authenticator, Authy, Microsoft Authenticator, or hardware-based tokens like YubiKey.
  • Ensure the solution integrates well with your existing security infrastructure and user management systems.

Implement MFA

  • Integrate MFA into your authentication process. This often involves modifying login workflows to include additional authentication steps.
  • Example setup for an online service:

Upon entering their username and password, users are prompted to enter a code generated by their authentication app or sent via SMS.
 

Enforce MFA Policies

  • Define and enforce policies around the use of MFA. Consider making MFA mandatory for accessing sensitive systems or data.
  • Set up policies to handle lost or unavailable authentication factors, such as backup codes or administrative resets.

Educate Users

  • Provide training and documentation to users on why MFA is important and how to use the chosen MFA method.
  • Offer support for users who might have difficulties setting up or using MFA.

Monitor and Review

  • Regularly review the effectiveness of your MFA implementation. Look for any security incidents that may indicate bypasses or failures in your MFA setup.
  • Monitor user compliance with MFA policies and address any areas where adherence may be lacking.

Maintain Security Standards

  • Keep the MFA solution updated to defend against new vulnerabilities.
  • Regularly evaluate new authentication methods and technologies to enhance security as needed.

Additional Considerations:

  • Be mindful of the user experience. Implementing MFA should balance security with usability. Overly complicated MFA processes can lead to user frustration or bypass attempts.
  • Consider the implications of relying on SMS-based authentication, as it can be less secure than other methods due to vulnerabilities in mobile networks.

By implementing MFA, you add a critical layer of security that protects against the most common threats to user accounts, particularly credential theft. This makes unauthorized access significantly more difficult, safeguarding your systems and data effectively.

reference.name: NIST Special Publication 800-63B

countermeasure.name: Use x-frame-options header
countermeasure.desc:
The X-Frame-Options HTTP header is used to control whether a web browser should be allowed to render a page in a <frame>, <iframe>, <embed>, or <object> tag. This header is an effective measure to prevent clickjacking attacks where an attacker tricks a user into clicking on something different than what the user perceives, thereby hijacking the user's intended action.

Choose an Appropriate Directive There are three directives you can set for the X-Frame-Options header:

  • DENY: No rendering within a frame, no matter the origin.
  • SAMEORIGIN: Only allows pages from the same origin as the page itself to be framed.
  • ALLOW-FROM uri: Allows pages to be framed but only by the specified uri.

Implement the Header in Your Web Server Depending on your server, you will need to add configuration to send the X-Frame-Options header. Here are configurations for common web servers:

  • Apache: Edit your .htaccess, httpd.conf, or vhost.conf file: Header always set X-Frame-Options "SAMEORIGIN"
  • Nginx: Add to your server configuration: add_header X-Frame-Options "SAMEORIGIN";
  • IIS: Add to your web.config:

<system.webServer>
 <httpProtocol>
   <customHeaders>
     <add name="X-Frame-Options" value="SAMEORIGIN" />
   </customHeaders>
 </httpProtocol>
</system.webServer>
 

Test Your Configuration

  • Deploy the changes to a test environment.
  • Use tools such as web security testing tools or browser developer tools to ensure the X-Frame-Options header is being sent correctly.
  • Test embedding your site in frames from other origins to ensure the policy works as expected.

Monitor and Adjust as Necessary

  • After deploying the X-Frame-Options header, monitor your application's logs and user feedback to detect any issues or unintended interactions caused by the policy.
  • Adjust the policy as needed based on the operational and security needs of your application.

Consider Modern Alternatives While the X-Frame-Options header is supported widely, consider implementing Content Security Policy (CSP) with the frame-ancestors directive for more granular control over framing. CSP is considered a more modern and flexible approach: Content-Security-Policy: frame-ancestors 'self' https://trusteddomain.com;
Additional Considerations:

  • Ensure all web servers and environments in your infrastructure are configured consistently to use the X-Frame-Options header.
  • Educate your development team about the risks of clickjacking and the role of HTTP headers like X-Frame-Options in mitigating these risks.

By using the X-Frame-Options header correctly, you strengthen your web applicationâ€™s defenses against clickjacking attacks, providing a safer and more secure environment for your users.

reference.name: OWASP Clickjacking Defense Cheat Sheet

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: An attacker can perform denial-of-service (DoS) attacks on the user interface
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

A Denial-of-Service (DoS) attack on the User Interface (UI) targets the elements that users interact with to disrupt service and render the application unusable. Unlike traditional network-level DoS attacks that saturate the server with traffic, UI-focused DoS attacks aim to overload or break the interface components, thereby preventing legitimate user actions and interactions. These attacks may involve flooding the UI with excessive requests, manipulating UI components to cause failures, or exploiting vulnerabilities that cause the application to hang or crash.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

The primary agents of UI DoS attacks are often external attackers who may not require authenticated access to the application. Attack vectors can include:

  • Automated scripts that repeatedly trigger heavy UI processes.
  • Exploitation of flaws in client-side scripts like JavaScript to initiate intensive operations that freeze the UI.
  • Abusive use of legitimate functions, such as overly complex search queries or rapid sequence actions that the UI isnâ€™t designed to handle efficiently.

Impacts:

The impacts of a UI DoS attack are significant and can include:

  • Degradation of application performance leading to slow response times or total unavailability.
  • Reduced productivity and potential revenue loss if users cannot complete transactions or access services.
  • Erosion of trust in the application's reliability, which might deter users from returning.

Example Attack Scenarios:

Scenario 1: An attacker develops a script that automates the process of opening and closing an advanced options menu in the application's UI rapidly and continuously. This menu requires significant processing power to render. The script triggers this function faster than the application can handle, leading to a buffer overflow error that crashes the application for all users.

Scenario 2: An e-commerce websiteâ€™s product search feature is exploited where the attacker sends complex, nested search queries at a high frequency. Each query is designed to be computationally expensive, invoking deep database searches and extensive result rendering efforts. The server remains operational, but the UI becomes irresponsive to legitimate user queries due to the load, effectively denying service.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: An attacker can perform clickjacking attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

Clickjacking, also known as a "UI redress attack," involves tricking a user into clicking on something different from what the user perceives, effectively hijacking the user's intended actions. This attack leverages embedded components, such as an invisible or disguised iframe, overlaid on legitimate UI elements. The attacker manipulates visibility and positioning to coax the user into performing actions like clicking on a button or link that triggers unintended operations. These operations could range from granting permissions and accessing camera or microphone to liking social media content or initiating financial transactions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

Clickjacking primarily exploits vulnerabilities in the way web applications handle UI layering and user input. Threat agents include:

  • Malicious website operators who embed the target application within an iframe on their site with deceptive overlays.
  • Adversaries distributing links through emails, social media, or other platforms that lead to such malicious pages.

Impacts:

The impacts of clickjacking can vary widely based on the nature of the unintended action but typically include:

  • Unauthorized actions performed on behalf of the user, leading to data theft, account compromise, or financial loss.
  • Compromised privacy, if permissions are manipulated to access hardware like cameras or microphones.
  • Erosion of user trust in the security of the application.

Example Attack Scenarios:

Scenario 1: A user visits a seemingly benign news article shared on social media. Unknown to the user, the page contains an invisible iframe overlaying a popular social networking site where the user is still logged in. The article prompts the user to click to "reveal" content, but the click actually submits a "change password" request on the social network, with the new password controlled by the attacker.

Scenario 2: An attacker sets up a fake game website where users are encouraged to click on various parts of the screen to interact with the game. However, each click is actually on an invisible overlay that causes the user to unknowingly purchase items on an e-commerce platform, using a session the user had previously authenticated but not logged out of.

threat.name: An attacker can perform UI redressing attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

UI redressing is a type of attack where an attacker manipulates the visual presentation of an application's user interface to deceive the user into performing unintended actions. This attack is closely related to clickjacking but can involve additional elements such as misleading visual cues, overlaying deceptive content, or rearranging UI components to induce errors. The goal is often to obtain sensitive information, trigger unauthorized commands, or mislead users into interacting with malicious elements.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

UI redressing can be executed by external attackers who may craft malicious web pages or applications that load the target UI elements in a deceptive manner. Common attack vectors include:

  • Embedding the legitimate application within a custom, deceptive frame or overlay.
  • Manipulating CSS and HTML to alter the appearance or layout of legitimate UI components.
  • Using floating elements or other graphical tricks to cover or modify the appearance of the real interface.

Impacts:

The impacts of UI redressing attacks include:

  • Unauthorized transactions or operations performed without the user's genuine consent.
  • Compromise of sensitive information, such as login credentials or personal data.
  • Damage to the userâ€™s trust in the applicationâ€™s integrity and security, potentially affecting the reputation and reliability of the service provider.

Example Attack Scenarios:

Scenario 1: An attacker designs a webpage that looks like a popular video streaming service's login page. The attacker's page is actually an overlay on the legitimate service. When users enter their credentials, they believe they are logging into the streaming service, but their username and password are sent to the attacker.

Scenario 2: A user visits a custom-crafted website that appears to offer a benign survey. However, the survey's "Submit" button is strategically placed over a digital wallet's "Send Money" button, which is loaded invisibly in the background via an iframe. As the user attempts to submit the survey, they unintentionally authorize a payment to an account controlled by the attacker.

These scenarios exploit the visual trust users have in familiar interfaces, turning ordinary interactions into harmful actions without the userâ€™s knowledge.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: An attacker can perform cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks occur when an attacker injects malicious scripts into web pages viewed by other users. These scripts can execute in the context of the user's session, allowing the attacker to bypass normal access controls and directly manipulate the user interface or steal sensitive information such as session tokens, cookies, or personal data. XSS attacks typically exploit vulnerabilities in web applications that fail to properly sanitize input data before including it in output.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

Threat agents include anyone with the ability to manipulate input fields where script injection is possible. Attack vectors are typically through:

  • User inputs that are improperly sanitized, allowing script injection into dynamically generated web pages.
  • Malicious payloads delivered via URL parameters, form fields, or even via manipulated documents that the user interacts with, such as PDFs or emails.

Impacts:

The impacts of XSS attacks can be severe, including:

  • Session hijacking, where attackers gain control of a user's active session.
  • Defacement of the website, which can damage the organizationâ€™s reputation.
  • Phishing attacks orchestrated through the trusted site by displaying deceptive content.
  • Installation of malware or initiating unauthorized transactions or actions on behalf of the user.

Example Attack Scenarios:

Scenario 1: An attacker places a malicious script in a comment on a public forum that lacks proper input sanitization. When other users view the comment, the script executes within their browser, stealing their session cookies and sending them back to the attacker. The attacker then uses these cookies to hijack the usersâ€™ sessions and gain unauthorized access to their accounts.

Scenario 2: A user receives an email with a link that appears to lead to a legitimate survey hosted by their bank. The link actually redirects to a version of the bank's login page that includes an XSS payload in the URL. When the user logs in, the script executes and captures their keystrokes, sending their username and password to the attacker.

In both scenarios, the attacker exploits the trust users have in the application's security, using the application itself as a vector to deliver harmful scripts.

weakness.name: CWE-1021
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1021: Improper Restriction of Rendered UI Layers or Frames The web application does not restrict or incorrectly restricts frame objects or UI layers that belong to another application or domain, which can lead to user confusion about which interface the user is interacting with. A web application is expected to place restrictions on whether it is allowed to be rendered within frames, iframes, objects, embed or applet elements. Without the restrictions, users can be tricked into interacting with the application when they were not intending to.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-79
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-79: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting') The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes user-controllable input before it is placed in output that is used as a web page that is served to other users.

weakness.name: CWE-922
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-922: Insecure Storage of Sensitive Information The product stores sensitive information without properly limiting read or write access by unauthorized actors. If read access is not properly restricted, then attackers can steal the sensitive information. If write access is not properly restricted, then attackers can modify and possibly delete the data, causing incorrect results and possibly a denial of service.

countermeasure.name: Avoid unsafe DOM manipulation and isolate untrusted scripts
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of a web client application, it is crucial to avoid the use of methods such as innerHTML and document.write for inserting dynamic content, as they can expose the application to Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks. Instead, implement JavaScript sandboxing techniques to restrict script execution and limit the impact of potential malicious code. Follow these steps to effectively apply these practices:

  1. Avoid using innerHTML and document.write:
    • Whenever possible, use textContent or innerText when inserting user-generated content into the DOM. These methods escape HTML, preventing the execution of any injected scripts.
    • For generating dynamic HTML content, use DOM manipulation methods like createElement, appendChild, or insertAdjacentElement.
  2. Implement Strict Content Security Policy (CSP):
    • Define a CSP policy that limits where resources can be loaded from and prevent inline scripts from executing without specific nonce or hash attributes.
    • Update the server configuration to include a secure CSP header. For example, configure your web server to send a header like: Content-Security-Policy: script-src 'self'.
  3. Utilize JavaScript sandboxing:
    • Use iframe elements with the sandbox attribute to run potentially untrusted scripts in a restricted execution environment.
    • Define sandbox rules to disable certain capabilities such as form submissions or plugin usage by including restrictions like sandox="allow-same-origin allow-scripts", while continuously adjusting these based on real application needs and security assessments.
  4. Apply libraries and frameworks for secure data binding:
    • Consider utilizing frontend frameworks such as React, Angular, or Vue.js, which inherently handle safe data binding and abstraction layers to reduce direct DOM manipulation.
    • These libraries offer protection features and methods against XSS due to their managed templating systems.
  5. Regularly update and audit code:
    • Ensure that your codebase and dependencies are regularly updated to mitigate known vulnerabilities.
    • Perform security audits and code reviews focusing on areas where user input impacts DOM manipulation.

By following these guidelines, you can mitigate risks associated with unsafe DOM manipulation and script execution, enhancing the overall security posture of your web client application.

References

  • MDN Web Docs - innerHTML Security Considerations
  • Content Security Policy (CSP) Reference
  • React Documentation - Introducing JSX
  • Angular Guide - Security

countermeasure.name: Detect and block UI redressing attempts
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of the web client by preventing clickjacking attacks, follow these JavaScript-based frame-busting implementation steps:

  1. Function Initialization: Ensure the JavaScript function is executed as soon as the document is loaded. This can be done by placing the script at the end of the HTML body or attaching it to the window's onLoad event as shown in the example.
    1. window.onLoad = function() {    // Detect if the page is in an iframe    if (window.top !== window.self) {        window.top.location = window.self.location;    } }
  2. Frame-busting Script Logic: Implement a simple check within your JavaScript to detect whether the current webpage is being loaded within an iframe. This can be achieved by checking if window.top is equal to window.self.
  3. Redirection: If the webpage is inside an iframe, redirect the top frame to the current page's location. This effectively pulls the website out of the iframe and prevents the site from being embedded.
  4. Deploy and Test: After embedding this script in your application, ensure it correctly prevents your page from being displayed in any iframe. Conduct thorough testing to verify that normal usage is unaffected while iframe attempts are appropriately blocked.
  5. Detecting Overlays: Use client-side scripts to detect unexpected overlays. This involves monitoring the DOM for unauthorized inserted elements.

For this, include event listeners on dynamic DOM changes using MutationObservers, and if any suspicious elements are detected, take actions, such as denying access to specific features or alerting the user.

const observer = new MutationObserver((mutations) => {    mutations.forEach((mutation) => {        // Logic to detect and respond to unauthorized overlay or UI changes        if (/* some condition to identify a suspicious DOM node */) {            alert('Suspicious activity detected!');            // Optionally take further action, like removing the element        }    }); }); observer.observe(document.body, { childList: true, subtree: true });

  1. Start Observing DOM: Use the MutationObserver API to watch changes in the DOM structure. Observe body elements to catch any suspicious insertions or changes.
  2. Define Conditions: Specify what constitutes an unexpected overlay based on your applicationâ€™s expected behavior and UI state. For instance, look for fullscreen unauthorized dialog boxes.
  3. Handle Detected Anomalies: If a breakpoint is detected, you can either alert the user directly or log out activities for further review while limiting available actions.

References

  • MDN Web Docs: Window.self
  • MDN Web Docs: MutationObserver
  • OWASP: Clickjacking Defense

countermeasure.name: Ensure secure communication and validate external resources
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your Web Client, it is crucial to enforce HTTPS with strong TLS (Transport Layer Security) configurations, ensuring the encryption and integrity of data transmitted between the client and server.

  1. Configure HTTPS:
    1. Obtain an SSL/TLS certificate from a trusted Certificate Authority (CA).
    2. Configure your web server (such as Apache, Nginx, or IIS) to use the obtained certificate. Refer to your server documentation for specific instructions.
    3. Ensure that all content, including images, scripts, and stylesheets, are served over HTTPS to avoid mixed content issues.
    4. Set up automatic HTTPS redirection by implementing HTTP to HTTPS redirects, ensuring that all traffic to your web client is encrypted.
  2. Implement Strong TLS Configurations:
    1. Disable outdated and vulnerable protocols (e.g., TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1) and enforce the use of TLS 1.2 or higher.
    2. Configure your web server to use strong cipher suites, removing support for weak ones. Ensure that Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS) is enabled to provide additional security.
    3. Regularly review and update your server configurations to adhere to the latest security guidelines and best practices.
  3. Disable HTTP/2 Prioritization Attack Risk:
    1. Ensure HTTP/2 prioritization is implemented correctly, or disable it if not needed, to prevent attack vectors that exploit the feature.
  4. Validate External Resources with Subresource Integrity (SRI):
    1. Edit the HTML of your web client to include the integrity attribute on any <script> or <link> tags that load content from external sources.
    2. Generate the integrity hash value for the resource. Use a tool like SRI Hash Generator by pasting the URL of the external resource or the content itself.
    3. Include the generated hash within the integrity attribute of your HTML tags, specifying a hash algorithm such as SHA-384 or SHA-512.
    4. Regularly audit and update the SRI hashes whenever external resources are updated to ensure proper validation continues.

References

  • Let's Encrypt - Getting Started
  • Mozilla Developer Network - HTTP Strict Transport Security
  • OWASP Transport Layer Protection Cheat Sheet
  • Mozilla Security Server Side TLS Guide
  • Mozilla Developer Network - Subresource Integrity

countermeasure.name: Prevent storage of sensitive data on the client
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of a web client, it's crucial to handle sensitive information such as authentication tokens, API keys, and personally identifiable information (PII) with care. Here's a step-by-step guide to ensuring these data types are protected:

  1. Assessment of Current Storage Practices:

    • Audit current methods for storing sensitive information within your web client.
    • Identify any instances where information is stored in local storage, session storage, or client-side databases.

  2. Implement Secure Storage Practices:

    • Avoid storing sensitive values like authentication tokens or API keys in session storage or local storage whenever possible to reduce the risk of exposure.
    • If unavoidable, use secure alternatives such as storing temporary session data on server-side sessions.

  3. Encryption of Data:

    • If local storage is imperative, leverage encryption to secure your data. Use the Web Crypto API to encrypt data before storing it on the client-side.
    • Generate a cryptographic key using the Web Crypto API's `generateKey` method.
    • Use the `subtle.encrypt` method of the Web Crypto API to encrypt sensitive data before storage.
    • Ensure you store the keys securely and consider using server-side sessions or a secure cookie-based mechanism for sensitive token and key exchange.

  4. Information Minimization:

    • Only store data that is absolutely necessary for client operation, reducing the amount of sensitive information available to potential attackers.

  5. Regular Security Reviews:

    • Conduct regular security reviews and penetration tests to ensure data storage practices remain secure against emerging vulnerabilities and threats.

References

  • MDN Web Crypto API Documentation
  • OWASP Top Ten - Sensitive Data Exposure
  • Google Developers - Store Credentials Securely

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Clickjacking
threat.desc:
General threat description
An attacker manipulates a web page by overlaying a hidden or disguised user interface element to deceive users into executing actions without their awareness.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Cybercriminals or malicious entities who create or distribute tampered HTML or JavaScript code that modifies the user interface on a web page.
Impacts
This can lead to unauthorized transactions, data breaches, or compromise of user data due to users being misled into clicking or entering information into malicious forms.
Example Attack Scenarios
A user visits a banking website where a strategically placed invisible button overlays the legitimate 'Submit' button, causing the user to unknowingly authorize a funds transfer to an attacker's account.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Cross-site scripting
threat.desc:
General threat description
An attacker can inject harmful scripts into a web page that execute in the victim's browser, causing unauthorized access to session information, theft of sensitive data, and forcing the user to perform unintended operations.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat actors typically use methods such as input fields, URLs, or stored data that are improperly validated or sanitized in web applications to introduce the malicious scripts.
Impacts
The compromise of user account confidentiality, integrity, and availability, leading to potential unauthorized access to sensitive account information, financial loss, or damage to user reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
A criminal leverages a vulnerable comment section on a website to post a script that captures cookies from users accessing the page, allowing the attacker to impersonate them for fraudulent transactions.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter

threat.name: Client-side insecure data storage
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper storage of sensitive information within the browser, such as authentication tokens or personal data, which can be extracted or manipulated by malicious entities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious attackers who are able to access and exploit vulnerabilities in the browser storage system to retrieve sensitive information.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to user accounts, potential identity theft, and breach of data privacy.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker injects a script into a web page that, when executed, retrieves authentication tokens improperly stored in browser local storage, allowing them to impersonate the user and access restricted areas of the web application. Another scenario involves an attacker leveraging a browser vulnerability to obtain personal data stored in cookies, which can then be used for unauthorized transactions.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1055.005 - Thread Local Storage

threat.name: Man-in-the-middle attacks
threat.desc:
General threat description
An adversary takes advantage of vulnerable communication channels by intercepting and altering messages exchanged between the web client and the server. This malicious activity can result in unintended exposure of sensitive data, compromise of user sessions, and execution of unauthorized operations.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Individuals or entities with access to the network path between the web client and server, potentially exploiting unsecured connections, such as public Wi-Fi, or leveraging malware to eavesdrop on and alter the communication. These adversaries might use tools to modify the traffic or credentials to intrude into the communication flow.
Impacts
The consequences of this threat can include privacy violations through data leaks, loss of control over user accounts due to session hijacking, and the possibility for the attacker to perform actions on behalf of the victim, leading to further unauthorized activities and damages.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. A user connects to a public Wi-Fi and accesses a web service; an attacker on the same network intercepts the unsecured traffic, gaining access to sensitive information input by the user. 2. An attacker implants malware on a victim's machine, which captures and modifies requests and responses between the web client and the server, possibly allowing unauthorized transactions in the victim's online banking session. 3. During a session, the attacker injects commands to perform actions under the user's credentials, such as changing account settings or initiating transfers, without the user's consent.
